Muhammad BilalHanif is currently employed as a Senior Researcher at the Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Comenius University in Bratislava, Slovakia. Additionally, he collaborates with the Polish Academy of Sciences in Krakow, Poland, under the guidance of Dr. hab. Michał Mosiałek. Recognizing his achievements, he has been honored with the Young Scientists award from XJTU, China, and has received the UK grant for the years 2021–2024 at Comenius University Bratislava, Slovakia. His research primarily focuses on solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, and solid-state batteries for energy conversion applications. item S2095-4956(24)00173-6 S2095495624001736 Graphical abstract This review analyses other reviews published since 2020 on solid oxide materials and related electrochemical cells. The performed comprehensive analysis reveals recent and prospective trajectories in both fundamental and applied fields. Complex oxides are an important class of materials with enormous potential for electrochemical applications. Depending on their composition and structure, such complex oxides can exhibit either a single conductivity (oxygen-ionic or protonic, or n-type, or p-type electronic) or a combination thereof generating distinct dual-conducting or even triple-conducting materials. These properties enable their use as diverse functional materials for solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, permeable membranes, and gas sensors. The literature review shows that the field of solid oxide materials and related electrochemical cells has a significant level of research engagement, with over 8,000 publications published since 2020. The manual analysis of such a large volume of material is challenging. However, by examining the review articles, it is possible to identify key patterns, recent achievements, prospects, and remaining obstacles. To perform such an analysis, the present article provides, for the first time, a comprehensive summary of previous review publications that have been published since 2020, with a special focus on solid oxide materials and electrochemical systems. Thus, this study provides an important reference for researchers specializing in the fields of solid state ionics, high-temperature electrochemistry, and energy conversion technologies. Keywords SOFCs SOECs PCFCs Electrochemistry Energy conversion Hydrogen energy, Carbon neutrality 1 Introduction Research and development activities carried out within the framework of hydrogen energy [1–6] and carbon emission neutrality [7–11] programs are obvious means to adjust the worldwide climate change, warming effect, and global pollution. Many countries have committed to participating in these programs by creating, adopting, and developing new technologies. However, these technologies are at different stages of implementation. According to various projections, green and sustainable technologies dealing with the use of renewable energy sources instead of the conventional fossil resources are proposed to be fully operational by 2050. Solid oxide electrochemical devices working at elevated temperatures (above 400 °C) belong to a convenient choice addressing the above-mentioned issues. Such devices include a great variety of electrochemical systems based on different operating principles, including power (co–)generation (in solid oxide fuel cells), hydrogen production, CO2-electrolysis (in solid oxide electrolysis cells), various electrochemical conversions (solid oxide reactors or converters), gas separation/purification (permeable membranes, solid oxide pumps), electrochemical analysis (solid-state sensors), and etc. Each of these systems is based on complex oxide materials with their unique conductivity behavior; these materials offer specific functions that enable the realization of different H- and C-based electrochemical processes. The literature analysis has shown that the field of solid oxide electrochemical materials and systems is currently highly studied. For instance, a Scopus search yields approximately 37,000 publications, including around 8,000 publications since 2020. It is obvious that such a huge amount of information is difficult to analyze in order to reveal the recent and current trends in materials science and electrochemical aspects. To address this shortcoming, we present the current work, which offers a comprehensive overview of review articles on solid oxide functional materials published from 2020 to the present. We believe that this work can be used as a guide to efficiently process a large amount of information and understand the potential use of oxide systems for electrochemical purposes. 2 Scientometric analysis of published items 2.1 Methodology A bibliometric analysis was performed based on 379 1 1 The current review cites 411 articles published within a period of 2020–2024, but 32 reviews are not properly processed for scientometric analysis due to their incomplete metadata. review articles from 2020–2023 on the topic of solid oxide materials and cells (Selection A), as well as the articles cited by them (Selection B). The Crossref database was used as the data source for the analysis. Data collection, analysis, and visualization were performed using the Requests, Pandas, and Matplotlib libraries of the Python 3 programming language, as well as the VOSviewer software [12]. A total of 31,661 English-language articles written by 48,813 scientists from 1,990 scientific journals published by 227 publishers were analyzed. Fig. 1 (a) displays the top 10 publishers in terms of the number of articles published on SOFCs. Most of the review articles (87.5% of Selection B) are published in scientific journals published by Elsevier B.V. (53.2%), American Chemical Society (8%), Wiley (6.9%), Springer Science and Business Media LLC (6.9%), Royal Society of Chemistry (6.6%) and The Electrochemical Society (5.9%). Fig. 1(b) shows the most active journals publishing articles on the considered topic (34.6% of Selection B). The International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, Journal of Power Sources, Solid State Ionics, and Journal of the Electrochemical Society are the leading journals in terms of the number of articles published. Keywords from article titles were analyzed using a pre-trained BERT neural network based on the transformer architecture. To achieve this the titles were divided into word tokens and fed into the BERT encoder's input to obtain embeddings which are vector representations of the titles. In the BERT neural network family an embedding is a 768-dimensional vector. The vector representations of closely related sentences are close. The cosine similarity between the title vectors was used as a measure of their closeness. This was calculated using the following equation (1) cos ϕ = a , b a 2 2 b 2 2 where a , b is a scalar product of the embeddings; a 2 2 and b 2 2 are the squares of the Euclidean norm of the embeddings. The cosine similarity tends to unity when the vector representations of similar phrases are co-added. We created a 'portrait' of a cited article on SOFCs using article metadata from the Crossref database and identified the leading groups of scientists based on the number of article citations. 2.2 Analysis of the rating of journals publishing articles on SOFC The quartile of a scientific journal is an indicator of its importance in the scientific community. It can be used to assess the relevance of journals publishing articles on a particular topic in general. Fig. 2 (a) shows the distribution of reviews on the considered topic by journal quartile. The majority of reviews from Selection A (63.9%) were published in first-quartile journals, indicating the relevance of research in the field of solid oxide electrochemical devices. The journals listed in Table 1 are the leaders in terms of the number of reviews published on the considered topic. Out of the 10 evaluated journals, 8 are in the first quartile, 1 is in the second quartile, and 1 has no quartile. 2.3 Article citation analysis As the number of studies in the field of solid oxide materials and cells continues to grow, it is becoming more challenging to select literature sources that can serve as primary information sources. Analyzing article citations can help identify the most important papers and promising research directions. In this paper, the number of reviews referring to the article was used as a criterion of significance. However, it is important to note that this value can be significantly influenced by the number of references per review. The number of references in different review articles varies considerably. Fig. 2(b) shows the density distribution plot of the number of citations in 379 review articles, published since 2020 on the topic of solid oxide materials and cells. As the number of citations is a non-negative value, its distribution is shifted to the right. Table 2 shows descriptive statistics of the distribution of the number of citations in reviews. According to the data in Table 2, the median reference number of review articles amounts 152 references. Using the median instead of the average (181 citations) provides a clearer estimation of the number of citation items due to the significant dispersion towards higher values (standard deviation – 143 citations). The time limits chosen can also impact the objectivity of article evaluations based on the number of citations, as this metric does not account for the time period over which the citations were accumulated. Fig. 2(c) displays the yearly distribution of articles on the selected topic (Selection B) that were cited by reviews from Selection A. The graph illustrates a decrease in the number of cited articles as the age of the article increases. It is important to note that articles published within the last 3 years may be cited less often due to their short lifespan. Thus, articles published between 2016 and 2023 are considered relevant as they have a longer lifespan and are cited more frequently than articles published before 2015. Table 3 summarizes the 10 articles from 2016–2023 on the considered topic, the most cited reviews from Selection A. According to the data in Table 3, research aimed at low- and intermediate-temperature SOFCs has been relevant in the last 7 years, mainly due to the use of proton-conducting materials as electrolytes. Eight of the 10 papers presented in Table 3 are dedicated to the study of proton-conducting electrolytes. Table 3 displays highly cited reviews, indicating the significance of research on LT- and IT-SOFC in the scientific community. Reducing the operating temperature of solid oxide electrochemical cells has a negative effect on the kinetics of the cathode processes. Therefore, studies aimed at finding cathode materials with high electrochemical activity against oxygen at reduced temperatures are relevant. Ding D. presented a review of the strategy for improving surface activity using the infiltration technique. 2.4 Analysis of keywords in article titles One of the factors that determines the popularity of an article in the scientific community is its relevance. Search requests in scientific databases such as Scopus, Web of Science, or Google Scholar retrieve articles that contain keywords entered by the user. By analysing the keywords in the titles of SOFC/SOEC-related articles, we can identify areas of research that are relevant today, as well as the attributes that search engines use to recommend articles to users. Fig. 2(d), build with VOSviewer software, shows a thematic map of the co-occurrence of author keywords (minimum value equal to 10) from the articles of Selection A. All author keywords used are grouped into three thematic clusters: yellow, violet, and blue. The articles dealing with the performance of SOFCs are integrated into the yellow cluster, while the articles dealing with the fabrication of SOFCs are integrated into the violet cluster. The blue cluster integrates the research on proton-conducting and electrolysis cells, showing the most relevant investigations in the field of SOFCs. It is important to note that there are numerous algorithms available for extracting keywords from textual data. Among these, neural network approaches have shown the most promise in identifying key information in text data. Neural networks are used to transform words, phrases, or whole sentences into a numerical vector of fixed size - embedding. Texts can be of any size, so the coordinates of the embedding will vary in absolute value. This means that similar texts can be represented by co-directional vectors. The cosine distance is a metric that reflects the degree of co-directionality of the embeddings. In this paper, the DistilBERT model, a neural network model based on the “transformer” architecture, was used to build embeddings of article titles. The most common phrases in the titles of articles from Selection B are “anode supported solid oxide fuel cells”, “spinel coating application for solid oxide fuel cell interconnects”, “electrode for intermediate temperature reversible solid oxide fuel cells”, “material selection for solid oxide fuel cell technology”, “anode materials for solid oxide fuel cells”, “various cell parameters”, “electrolyte supported solid oxide fuel cells”, “interface of anode supported solid oxide fuel cells”, “modeling cell resistance of anode supported solid oxide fuel cells”. For example, studies on SOFC design and electrode material selection are ongoing. According to the data, anode supported fuel cell designs are the most common. 2.5 Leaders in the field of SOFCs research As the total number of authors of all reviewed articles was 37,874, we also used the VOSviewer software to define the leading authors of articles from Selection A. We created a map of authors (with a minimum of 3 reviews) shown in Fig. 2(e), and a map of authors’ countries, shown in Fig. 2(f). Additionally, we conducted an evaluation of scientists whose work has been acknowledged by the scientific community, based on the number of citations of review articles from Selection A. Table 4 shows the ranking of scientists whose work is most frequently cited in the selected reviews. From the data in Fig. 2(e and f) and Table 4, it can be inferred that the primary electrochemists involved in SOFC research are scientists from the People's Republic of China. 2.6 Conclusions on the scientometric analysis This paper analyses 379 review articles published since 2020 on solid oxide materials and electrochemical cells, along with their citations. The analysis was conducted using the Crossref and Scimago Journal Rankings databases. In total, 31,661 articles were analyzed, written by 48,813 scientists from around the world. The metadata analysis was used to create a 'portrait' of an average review on SOFC. On average, each of the 379 reviews analyzed contains 152 references. The majority of the papers cited in the reviews are published in journals such as Journal of Power Sources, International Journal of Hydrogen Energy, Solid State Ionics, and Journal of the Electrochemical Society. In the past 7 years, the most frequently cited reviews have focused on reducing the operating temperature of SOFCs. These papers primarily examine the properties of proton-conducting electrolytes and the development of cathode materials with high electrochemical activity for oxygen reduction reactions at low to intermediate temperatures. The analysis of paper titles suggests that relevant articles focus on designing SOFCs with a supporting anode and studying electrode reaction kinetics. 3 Classification of materials for solid oxide electrochemical objects The various types of electrochemical devices can be classified based on their operating principles. However, these cells are typically composed of materials with similar functionality, leading to a more general classification based on the conductivity behavior of constituent functional materials that cover all high-temperature electrochemical aspects. Complex oxides can exhibit four types of conductivity at elevated temperatures [23–29]: oxygen-ionic, p-type electronic, n-type electronic, and protonic (Fig. 3 a). These conductivities are caused by the corresponding charge carriers (oxygen vacancies, holes, electrons, and protons), which are stable in a crystal structure and able to move along it in the presence of a certain type of potential (chemical potential, temperature gradient, electric field, etc.). When one type of conductivity predominates over the other, so-called unipolar conductors can form. For example, unipolar (or pure) oxygen conductivity takes place for doped ZrO2 [30–32] and doped LaGaO3 materials [33]; (La,Sr)MnO3- and La(Ni,Fe)O3-based complex oxides [34–36] exhibit predominantly p-type electronic conductivity, while doped BaCeO3 and doped BaZrO3 are characterized by unipolar proton conductivity in humid reduced atmospheres at temperatures below 600 °C [37,38]. When two types of conductivity are comparable under certain experimental conditions, the materials are called mixed conductors. The latter can be divided into two subclasses: mixed ionic (co-ionic) conductors, when oxygen-ionic conductivity coexists with the protonic-one [39,40], and mixed ionic-electronic conductors (MIECs [41–44]), which represent systems with a combination of ionic and electronic conductivities. Complex oxides can simultaneously exhibit three types of conductivity, making them a class of triple-conducting materials [45–47]. It should be mentioned that each conductivity depends on the external conditions and the nature of the considered materials. For example, single-phase complex oxides based on cerates or zirconates of alkaline earth elements can have unipolar protonic, co-ionic, mixed ionic-electronic, or even triple conductivity. These variations are influenced by external factors such as temperature, oxygen partial pressure, and water vapor pressure. In addition, composite materials can create mixed conductivity by combining components with different conductivity behaviors. Based on the given classification, the complex oxides in both single phase and composite forms can be used as the following functional materials of solid oxide electrochemical cells. (1) Electrolytes, when exhibit predominantly oxygen-ionic, protonic, or co-ionic conductivity. (2) Electrodes (anodes, cathodes), when notable ionic conductivity exists along with high electronic conductivity. (3) Current collectors and interconnectors with very high electronic conductivity, regardless of the ionic conductivity level. (4) Glass sealants with extremely low both ionic and electronic conductivities. (5) Protecting layers or coatings with either pure ionic or pure electronic conductivity. (6) MIEC (electrode-free) membranes with comparable ionic and electronic conductivity values. The next sections highlight the recent fundamental and applied achievements for the functional materials used in solid oxide electrochemical cells. 4 Electrolytes An electrolyte is a heart of many solid oxide systems, which operate on different principles, Fig. 3 (b). Such systems include conventional oxygen-conducting solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), electrolysis cells (SOECs), pumps, sensors, as well as those based on proton-conducting electrolytes, i.e., protonic ceramic fuel cells (PCFCs), electrolysis cells (PCECs), and protonic ceramic converters (PCCs). The electrolyte plays an important role in the electrochemical conduction of ions and should therefore meet a number of stringent requirements [48–52]. (1) Good densification without through (across) pores to separate cathode and anode gases and to prevent their mechanical mixing. (2) High ionic and low electronic conductivities for both oxidized and reduced conditions to avoid internal electronic leakage. (3) High chemical stability against its chemical interaction with gas components or oxidized/reduced atmospheres at elevated temperatures. (4) High chemical compatibility with other functional materials to ensure no formation of low conductive interaction products (phases) at interfaces. (5) Thermo- and chemo-mechanical compatibilities to maintain good adhesion of interfaces and to prevent the occurrence of volume defects (cracks, delamination) during heating/cooling and thermal/redox/voltage cycling. (6) Low cost for the initial electrolyte components, their synthesis, and the fabrication of electrochemical cells with thin film electrolytes. From an objective perspective, there is no ideal electrolyte system that satisfies all of these requirements. Therefore, researchers are faced with the need to search for a compromise between the main target functions. As a result, continuous modification of already known oxide systems as well as the design of new electrolyte systems are still non-erasable directions in the fields of solid state ionics and electrochemistry [48,51,53,54]. 4.1 Oxygen-ionic electrolytes 4.1.1 ZrO2-based electrolytes ZrO2-based oxides are commonly used as electrolytes in SOFC and SOEC applications [34,55,56]. To achieve acceptable conductivity values, the basic zirconia phase needs its stabilization to a cubic state (as shown in Fig. 4 a), which can be realized through aliovalent doping, including trivalent (Y3+, Yb3+, Sc3+) or divalent (Ca2+, Mg2+) dopants. The introduction of such dopants creates oxygen vacancies, which are responsible for the oxygen-ionic conductivity of the complex oxides. Among ZrO2-based electrolytes, YSZ (yttria-stabilized zirconia) and ScSZ (scandia-stabilized zirconia) are the best-known representatives [48]. The materials in the former class demonstrate high chemical and thermal stability. However, the ionic conductivity of YSZ remains low due to defect association (at high stabilization degrees) and lattice strains caused by ionic radii differences between Zr4+ and Y3+ ions. In these terms, Sc-containing zirconia materials are found to be more conductive: ∼100 mS cm−1 can be achieved at 800 °C, which is by 2–4 times higher compared to the ionic conductivity of YSZ. Although ScSZ materials have better transport properties, they are subject to severe aging, resulting in a high degree of conductivity degradation at elevated temperatures. To mitigate this issue, a co-doping strategy [30] is employed, which involves the simultaneous application of different dopants (Y3+/Sc3+ or Sc3+/Ce4+). This strategy aims to stabilize the cubic structure of zirconia over a wide temperature range and minimize lattice stress for favorable oxygen-ion migrations. The literature analysis has shown that the Sc-containing zirconia electrolytes have attracted considerable attention of researchers, since several review articles have been published recently [57–59]. In detail, Zhigachev et al. [57] analyzed the transport properties of ScSZ (including in long-term perspective) upon utilizing the co-doping strategy and new preparation techniques. Their analysis shows that Bi2O3 together with CeO2 are suitable co-dopant for ScSZ, while Y2O3, Yb2O3 and Gd2O3 worsen its ionic conductivity despite of the stabilization of ScSZ cubic structure. In contrast, the review by Arifin et al. [58] suggests that lanthanide oxides with large Ln3+ ionic radii (i.e., Gd3+, Sm3+, and Nd3+) could be potential dopants for ScSZ. In addition to the electrolyte properties, this review summarizes the existing data on the corresponding cermets in terms of their carbon deposition tolerance, showing that Ni–ScSZ cermets have better cracking ability than Ni–YSZ counterparts. Zakaria and Kamarudin [59] analyzed the functional properties of ScSZ, highlighting the current limitations and advantages of such materials. It should be pointed out that the materials science aspects of stabilized zirconia, as a reference oxygen-ionic electrolyte, have been largely elucidated over the last few decades. As a result, current research activities in chemical design and fundamental research of ZrO2-based electrolytes are somewhat reduced compared to the active investigations related to other representatives of oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes. However, all commercially available SOFCs and SOECs are composed of ZrO2-based electrolytes, indicating that zirconia is still extremely important from applied and commercial viewpoints. Another important aspect related to the zirconia electrolytes is related to the fact that their electrochemical cells have been tested for a long period of time, up to 100,000 h. No similar long-term studies have been carried out for other types of electrolytes. 4.1.2 CeO2-based electrolytes Doped CeO2 materials belong to another well-studied fluorite-structured class of oxygen-ionic electrolytes (Fig. 4b). Ceria can form a wide range of Ce1– x M x O2– δ solid solutions (M is the Y, lanthanides, alkaline-earth elements), whose conductivity exceeds that of YSZ by ∼1 order of magnitude or even more at 500–900 °C [30]. Being more chemically compatible (compared to YSZ) with various electrode materials, doped ceria can be used not only as electrolytes for SOFCs, but also as interlayers for ZrO2-based SOFCs and SOECs. This prevents a number of undesirable interfacial processes such as intense cationic interdiffusion and impurity phase formation [60–62]. The oxygen-ionic conductivity of doped CeO2 is a complex signal of many chemical and technological factors. Therefore, extensive research has been conducted to optimize the conductivity of CeO2-based ceramics. For example, the review of Anirban and Dutta [63] summarizes the effect of various factors (synthesis process, sintering conditions, dopant concentration, co-doping, dopant vacancy interaction, dopant ionic radius, grain boundary, grain size) on the bulk and grain boundary transport of single-doped and co-doped CeO2, as summarized in Fig. 4(c). According to their analysis, the following conclusions were formulated: (1) Gd3+ and Sm3+ in amounts of 15–25 mol% are the most suitable choice in terms of achieving high ionic conductivity, (2) the use of solution techniques or sintering aids facilitates the low-temperature densification of CeO2-based ceramics, (3) co-doping strategy in terms of optimized dopants can reduce dopant vacancy interaction and further increase the ionic conductivity. To improve the ionic conductivity of ceria materials, it is necessary to have a deep understanding of their structure and defect chemistry. In this regard, Schmitt et al. [64] provide a critical review that describes the defect-induced local distortion and short-range defect association with using complementary techniques of synchrotron X-ray absorption fine structure and Raman spectroscopy. These techniques allow the authors to conclude that local environments around defects strongly deviate from fluorite symmetry and that these are the source of some of its unusual mechanical properties, such as anelasticity and large electrostriction. Another feature of ceria materials is their ability to undergo a partial Ce4+-to-Ce3+ transition under reducing atmospheres, resulting in a high n-type electronic conductivity. The latter can be a source of leakage current in SOFCs and SOECs, which reduces their open circuit voltage and overall efficiency. In addition, due to lattice strain caused by the ionic size mismatch between Ce4+ and Ce3+ ions, such a reduction can cause mechanical destruction of the ceria electrolyte. Two recent works [65,66] have examined the causes of the incomplete reduction of doped CeO2 electrolytes and proposed potential solutions to prevent such adverse effects under the operating conditions of SOFCs and SOECs. In summary, two methods can be employed to achieve this goal. The first is based on the optimization of operating SOFC/SOEC conditions, including the application of highly active electrode materials, the humidification of a fuel to reduce oxygen partial pressure and temperature decrease. The second approach belongs to the utilization of electron-blocking layers (ZrO2, Bi2O3, BaCeO3), which exhibit pure ionic conductivity under reducing atmospheres, suppressing the overall leakage current in CeO2-based electrochemical cells. 4.1.3 Other electrolytes While zirconia and ceria materials have been extensively studied as electrolytes for SOFCs and SOECs, there are other promising classes of materials with non-fluorite structures. Two perovskite-related oxides, LaAlO3 and LaGaO3, are potential bases for the design of oxygen-ionic conductors. Depending on the type and amount of dopants introduced, LaAlO3-based materials can crystallize in either rhombohedral or cubic perovskite structures, while lower symmetries (orthorhombic) are found for LaGaO3-based materials [33,67,68]. Both systems have acceptable thermal expansion coefficients ranging between 10×10–6 and 13×10–6 K−1, which are close to those of zirconia ((10–11)×10–6 K−1) and ceria ((12–13)×10–6 K−1) materials. However, aluminates and gallates differ significantly in terms of transport properties. For example, A-site doped, B-site doped, and A-/B- co-doped LaAlO3 aluminates exhibit conductivity values at 700–900 °C below 16, 12, and 50 mS cm−1, respectively. Conversely, co-doped gallates are considered one of the most conductive oxygen-ionic systems, displaying 120–150 mS cm−1 at 800 °C. These values exceed those of most of the doped ZrO2 and CeO2 analogues allowing such gallates to be used in the design of high-performance electrolyte-supported SOFCs and SOECs. Although gallates have advantages, they also have several limitations. One of these limitations is the need for high sintering temperatures to achieve the desired densification of the gallates while maintaining their single-phase structure. During sintering or long-term treatments, several impurity phases (Sr3La4O9, SrLaGa3O7, SrLaGaO4) are often formed in the LaGaO3 system. These impurities have lower (from 2 to 7 orders of magnitude [62]) ionic conductivity compared to those of the doped/co-doped LaGaO3, which is a reasonable reason for deterioration of both conductivity of such electrolytes and the performance of the corresponding electrochemical cells. Gallates may also face limitations at high sintering temperatures due to possible gallium evaporation and chemical incompatibility with Ni-containing electrode phases. New synthesis approaches are currently being developed to create dense gallates using reduced sintering regimes. Pyrochlore-based phases, A2B2O7, have recently received significant attention. While some of these phases have been proposed for electronic applications due to their unique dielectric properties [69], others are more suitable for high-temperature applications [70,71]. For example, Anantharaman and Dasari [70] overview the potential of Nb-, Zr-, Ti-, and Mn-based pyrochlores as functional SOFC/SOEC materials. Among them, Gd-, Nd-, and Sm-based zirconates doped with magnesium or calcium exhibit oxygen-ionic conductivity values of 3–10 mS cm−1 at 800 °C, while other pyrochlores might show either mixed ionic-electronic or co-ionic behaviors. The review [70] presents the factors that affect the ionic conductivity of pyrochlore-type oxides, along with the results of the conductivity increase, as shown in Fig. 4(d). In a comprehensive review of Yang et al. [72], the authors concentrated their attention on various complex oxides containing tetrahedral moieties, including apatite, melitite, LAMOX, scheelite, mayenite, cuspidine derived oxides, and others. Along with a detailed description of the structural features of these phases, their transport properties are also summarized. For example, higher ionic conductivities (than that of YSZ) are reported for La1.54Sr0.46Ga3O7+ δ melilite, Bi0.85Ca0.15VO4– δ scheelite, La0.8Ba1.2GaO4– δ , Bi0.913V0.087O4– δ fluorite, and Ba7Nb4MoO20 hexagonal perovskite materials. It should be noted that among the varieties presented, there are many Ga-based phases with high potential for their use as SOFC or SOEC electrolytes, these includes doped La2Ga3O7+ δ , LaGaO4– δ , La4GaTiO9.5, LaSr2GaO5, BaYGa2O7+ δ [72,73]. In addition to single-phase materials, there is another approach related to the design of composite or heterostructure electrolytes [66,74–78]. The main goal in the development of composite electrolytes links with the target tailoring nature of their conductivity either to suppress the electronic conductivity of one phase by another or to introduce a new sort of ionic conductivity with creating dual-ion conducting materials. Heterostructure electrolytes usually consist of a bilayer design. One layer serves to eliminate the electronic conductivity of the second layer or acts as a protective layer to prevent cationic interdiffusion between poorly compatible functional materials. It is important to note that composite and heterostructure electrolytes may undergo chemical reactions between the two phases. Furthermore, the microstructural characteristics of the phases/layers and their fraction/thickness have a significant impact on the ohmic resistance of these systems. 4.2 Proton-conducting electrolytes Proton-conducting complex oxides discovered in the beginning of 1980 belong to a class of highly studied functional materials to be used for various protonic ceramic electrochemical cells. There is a numerous number of current research published from 2020 confirming high expectations for their real application in low- and intermediate-temperature electrochemical devices. The advantages of proton-conducting oxides over their oxygen-ionic counterparts consist in lower working temperatures (400–700 °C), which enables high ionic (protonic) conductivity to be achieved owing to the low size and mass of protons as charge carriers coupled with their high mobility [79–82]. Analyzing the current research activities in the field of proton-conducting electrolytes, four main directions can be identified in the existing reviews. (1) Theory of proton transport, including the formation and interaction of proton charge carriers, their effects on crystal structure, physico-chemical and functional properties, and the characterization of protons via various experimental and computational techniques [83–88]. (2) Detailed analysis of proton transport for already known and new proton-conducting materials with different crystal structures, including perovskites, fergusonites/scheelites, fluorites/pyrochlores, perovskite-related oxides, materials of a Ruddlesden-Popper family, and etc. [38,89–91]. (3) Revealing the main limitations of proton-conducting materials in terms of their further applications in electrochemical devices [39,49,92–95], including chemical stability, chemical compatibility, thermal compatibility, ionic conductivity, electronic conductivity, sinterability, etc. (4) Applied features of proton-conducting electrolytes in the electrochemical devices with the optimization of their performance & efficiency at low- and intermediate-temperature ranges [79,82,96,97]. 4.2.1 BaCeO3-based materials Barium cerate (BaCeO3) is a well-known family of proton conducting oxides that has been extensively studied in the period 1990–2010. Doped BaCeO3 materials exhibit the highest (total) proton conductivity ever reported (up to 100 mS cm−1 at 700–800 °C). This is due to a favorable combination of crystalochemical factors, including the low electronegativities of the basic cations, their high ionic radii, and large lattice volume. These factors contribute to the weakening of M−O bonds, resulting in high oxygen ionic conductivity in dry atmospheres and high protonic conductivity in humid atmospheres. Despite these achievements, BaCeO3 based materials suffer from low chemical stability associated with the decomposition of perovskite phases in CO2-containing environments and even in the presence of H2O (at temperatures below 500 °C [59,91]). Such a decomposition results in the formation of BaCO3, Ba(HCO3)2, Ba(OH)2, and CeO2 phases, which completely inhibit the proton conductivity of the parent cerate phase. To mitigate the undesirable formation of impurities, various stabilizing dopants (In3+, Ti4+, Sn4+, Zr4+, Hf4+, Th4+, Ta5+) can be introduced into the Ce-sublattice upon its partial substitution. As a result, the resulting multi-doped cerates exhibit improved chemical stability, but some other functional properties may be degraded. For example, the Ti-containing cerates may display high electronic conductivity under reduced atmospheres, the densification of Sn- and Zr-containing cerates becomes worse, the oxygen vacancy concentration of the Ta-containing cerates decreases due to a donor character of tantalum. Information on similar doped BaCeO3-compounds is summarized in an old review [98]. 4.2.2 BaZrO3-based materials Barium zirconate (BaZrO3) is another well-studied representative of proton-conducting electrolytes, demonstrating superior chemical stability in H2O– and CO2-containing gas atmospheres. In addition, its bulk proton conductivity is reported to be comparable to that of BaCeO3-based materials, making BaZrO3 a good basis for the design of state-of-the-art electrolytes. Several review articles have been published recently on barium zirconate materials [37,99–104]. Regalado-Vera et al. [102] provide a concise overview of the key proton transport parameters of zirconates, including the thermodynamics of their hydration, the effects of defect association and proton trapping on hydration, and their proton and electronic conductivity properties. Hossain et al. [37,101] have reviewed the materials science and electrochemical aspects of barium zirconate materials. In terms of materials science, the authors have carried out a comparative analysis of grain growth and relative density, level, and type of conductivity, selecting the most promising materials. From an applied point of view, they have analyzed the progress of BaZrO3-based materials as electrolytes for hydrogen sensors, hydrogen pumps, and protonic ceramic fuel cells. Rasaki et al. [100] also analyze the scientific and technological achievements of BaZrO3-based electrolytes, covering their synthesis and sintering characteristics, densification and grain size parameters, recent trends in chemical design and manufacturing methods of electrolytes. In addition, the authors provide some general information on the design of BaZrO3-derived electrode materials upon the introduction of high amounts of Co– and/or Fe ions to create triple-conducting electrodes. The detailed information on the achievements and prospects of triple-conducting phases is also provided in recent reviews [45,105,106]. Nayak and Sasmal [99] focused their attention on the synthesis characteristics of barium zirconates as refractory materials. In this regard, solid state reaction, combustion, sol–gel, hydrothermal synthesis approaches were thoroughly considered for the preparation of massive and thin film electrolytes. This, along with the work of Li et al. [107], represents the achievements in densification of high-quality zirconate ceramics. 4.2.3 Ba(Ce,Zr)O3-based materials A family of barium cerate-zirconates has been proposed as a rational alternative to barium cerates and barium zirconates in terms of achieving a trade-off between ionic conductivity, chemical stability, and sinterability. These functions are vital for the real application of Ba(Ce,Zr)O3-based electrolytes in various electrochemical devices. Considering specific reviews, only three have been recently published on this topic [82,108,109]. Hanif et al. [82] analyzed the recent trends in the chemical design of cere-zirconates for their application in proton ceramic electrolysis cells (PCECs), i.e., for high-temperature steam electrolysis. Starting with a discussion of classical examples of cerates and zirconates, the authors explain the reasons for focusing on BaCe1– x – y Zr x M y O3– δ materials (where M = Y, Sc, Yb in case of mono-doping or a combination of dopants in case of co-doping, 0.05 ≤ y ≤ 0.2, 0.1 ≤ x ≤ 1–y). Although Y-containing cerate-zirconates have been widely investigated, these materials exhibit poor chemical compatibility with Ni-cermets during high-temperature co-firing. Specifically, a BaY2NiO5 phase can be easily formed for Ba(Ce,Zr,Y)O3/NiO pairs. BaY2NiO5 inhibits proton transport of the pristine perovskite phase of cerate-zirconates [49,92], resulting in conductivity and performance degradation. To overcome these problems, a strategy of partial or complete substitution of yttrium with Sc3+, Yb3+, Dy3+, Gd3+ is proposed. Among these dopants, Y-/Yb- co-doped cerate-zirconates (labeled as BZCYYb or BCZYYb) have been identified as the most promising multi-doped derivatives. In another paper, Syafkeena et al. [108] reviewed the technological challenges of fabricating cerate-zirconate in thin film forms on the anode-supported PCFCs as well as their co-sintering to achieve gas-tight films. Fig. 4(e) summarizes the factors influencing the ionic conductivity of cerate-zirconates as discussed in the conclusion section of the review [108]. The preparation of thin films is also discussed in several other reviews [110–118]. Finally, the technological aspects of barium cerate-zirconate thin films have been analyzed in the work of Winiarz et al. [109]. In detail, the authors summarized the different approaches for the formation of such films (pulsed laser deposition, magnetron sputtering, electron beam deposition, powder aerosol deposition, atomic layer deposition and spray deposition) in relation to morphology quality and electrical properties. They found strong correlations between interface layers, space charge layers, strain-modified layers and the total conductivity of Ba(Ce,Zr)O3-based thin films. These correlations should be considered when designing multilayer electrochemical cells. 4.2.4 Other proton-conducting materials In addition to BaCeO3- and BaZrO3- based materials, several other classes of proton-conducting materials have recently been reviewed. Among the perovskite-related oxides, those based on barium stannate (BaSnO3 [119]), alkaline earth hafnates (MHfO3, M = Ca, Sr, Ba [120]), lanthanum scandates [121], lanthanum yttrates and ytterbates (LaMO3, M = Y, Yb [122]) are also interesting research objects. In many cases, these perovskites compete with zirconates and cerate-zirconates in terms of chemical stability and proton conductivity. However, they also possess unique properties. For instance, hafnates are known for their high stability, even in H2S-containing atmospheres. Doped barium stannates, on the other hand, exhibit exceptional hydration capability, approaching theoretical levels even at high concentrations of accepted dopants. In contrast, yttrates/ytterbates have low hydration capability due to their structural features, but they demonstrate predominantly protonic ionic conductivity under humid conditions. The work of S. Fop [38] thoroughly considers proton-conducting oxides with alternative structure types. Fop's review provides experimental data on the proton transport for various perovskite-related compounds, including hexagonal perovskites (Ba7Nb4MoO20, Ba5Er2Al2ZrO13, Ba4M2O9, where M = Nb, Sb, Ta), Ruddlesden-Popper phases (BaNdInO4, BaNdScO4), brownmillerite materials (Ba2In2O5, Ba2InGaO5, Ba2ScGaO5). Other structural types were also briefly considered, including ortho-niobates (doped LaNbO4) and ortho-tantalates (doped LaTaO4), gallates (LaBaGaO4, RE3Ga5MO14, where RE = La, Nd and M = Si, Ti, Sn, Ta), apatites (La9.6Si6O26.4, La9.67Ge6O26.5), pyrochlores (doped La2Zr2O7 and La2Ce2O7), tungstates (La27W5O55.5− δ , La5.5WO11.25− δ , La6WO12). It is clear that the discovery of new solid oxide proton conductors is crucial for gaining a fundamental understanding of the structure and mechanistic relationships. Ruddlesden-Popper (RP) phases, capable of pronounced proton conduction, are interesting objects in terms of their crystal structure with possible organization of point defects in both anionic and interstitial sites. Tarasova and Animitsa have provided the detailed reviews [123,124], analyzing the transport properties of origin and doped BaNdInO4, BaNdScO4, SrLaInO4, and BaLaInO4 phases. According to their analysis, the basic BaLaInO4 system is considered to be the most promising due to the realization of the highest proton conductivity values (among other RP phases) coupled with very high water uptake, ∼1.5 mol H2O per formula unit. Recently, Choudhary et al. [71] presented an in-depth analysis of La2Ce2O7 complex oxides and derivatives, including their crystal structures, hydration behavior, mechanism of ionic (oxygen-ionic and protonic) conductivity, catalytic behavior, operating temperature, and ease of processing. The authors critically discussed the possible (pyrochlore or distorted fluorite) structures of La2Ce2O7 and provided an overview of La2Ce2O7 as catalysts and various components (electrolyte, cathode, anode) of SOFCs and SOECs. Similarly, Xiang et al. [125] reviewed proton transport in complex oxides with fluorite (based on zirconia, ceria) and pyrochlore (lanthanide zirconates, stannates, and titanates) structures, as well as their potential electrochemical applications. The authors reported that while the proton conductivity of these compounds remains low, their chemical stability is excellent. Although the use of proton-conducting fluorite/pyrochlore oxides as PCFC electrolytes is currently challenging, they can serve as a buffer layer to prevent contact of Ba(Ce,Zr)O3 materials with the CO2 gas component or to reduce the leakage current for the related PCFCs/PCECs. Lim and Kitagawa [126] observed an application of proton-conducting porous metal–organic frameworks in solid-state electrolytes. This observation highlights the potential of these frameworks in the development of solid-state electrolytes. 4.3 Research activity in electrolyte materials Section 4 demonstrates that the topic of electrolytes is a primary area of research. According to a Scopus analysis (Fig. S1), over 1000 papers are published annually, with a majority focused on conventional oxygen-conducting electrolytes. However, the study of proton-conducting materials continues to grow, with up to 300 annual publications. Therefore, the mentioned review articles aim to assist researchers in comprehending existing information. 5 Oxygen electrodes Oxygen electrodes are a broad class of complex oxide materials that enable the realization of electrochemical reactions involving oxygen in its various (ionic, atomic, molecular) forms. Oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) are two of the most common processes that take place at oxygen electrodes in fuel cell and electrolysis operation modes, respectively, [127,128]. An ideal oxygen electrode material must simultaneously fulfill the following requirements [129–133]. (1) High electronic conductivity combined with an acceptable ionic (oxygen-ionic, protonic, or co-ionic) conductivity. (2) Phase and structural stability under oxidizing atmospheres at elevated temperatures (from 400 to 1000 °C). (3) High chemical stability under H2O and CO2 gas components. (4) Chemical compatibility with electrolyte and interconnect materials. (5) Thermo-mechanical and chemico-mechanical compatibility with joint functional materials. (6) High porosity for delivery of reactants to the interface and removal of reaction products from the interface. (7) High long-term morphology stability under high temperatures, (8) Low cost of oxygen electrode preparation and fabrication. Due to the greater variety of possible candidates for oxygen electrodes, the related systematical reviews for a period of 2020–2023 [35,47,128–147] are much higher than a number of reviews devoted to electrolyte materials. These reviews provide all the necessary information about oxygen electrodes, including chemical design of their basic compositions, chemical engineering of functional electrodes, technological aspects of fabrication and application, and long-term stability. Below, the main classes of oxygen electrodes are briefly presented and discussed. 5.1 Co-based electrodes Co-based perovskites (their structure is schematically shown in Fig. 5 a) are considered one of the most promising oxygen electrodes in terms of their electrochemical activity towards ORR kinetics. Therefore, it is unsurprising that the state-of-the-art electrodes for SOFCs and SOECs are based on LaCoO3 or BaCoO3 perovskites. Zhang et al. [148] provided a brief consideration of the crystal and electronic structures for pure and doped LaCoO3 and their effects on the OER activity. Two possible designs for good electrodes were mentioned: (1) partial replacement of basic cations with different dopants (for A-, B-sites of ABO3 perovskite or both sites simultaneously) at the materials level, and (2) surface and interfacial engineering at the level of multilayer structures. Kumar and Khandale [149] performed a detailed review of cobalt-based electrodes with single and double perovskite structures. Comparing two basic systems, BaCoO3 and SrCoO3, their attention was mainly focused on the latter in terms of the lower chemical reactivity of SrCoO3 (SC) with CO2-containing atmospheres. According to their analysis, pure SC has a high conductivity up to 150 S cm−1 at 900 °C. However, this high conductivity level is associated with poor stability of the SC phase at temperatures below 900 °C due to a phase transition from 3C-cubic to 2H-hexagonal structure, which impairs oxygen-ion transport. To overcome this shortcoming, substitution (doping) strategies for SC have been further analyzed. The doping can be performed for Sr-, Co-sites or both sites simultaneously. It was emphasized that each type of doping has its own functions. For example, partial substitution of cobalt with scandium, iron, nickel, copper effectively decreases TECs due to hindered Co4+-to-Co3+ reduction, partial doping of cobalt with high valence dopants (such as Nb5+, Ta5+, Sb5+, Mo6+) stabilizes the cubic structure of SC, provides high mixed ionic-electronic conductivity, and improves chemical stability toward carbonate formation. Considering the A-site substitution, Sm- and La-containing phases (La1– x Sr x CoO3– δ and Sm1– x Sr x CoO3– δ ) are well studied. In detail, an increase in strontium content leads to an improvement in oxygen transport due to the formation of additional oxygen vacancies but can also lead conductivity deterioration and TEC growth. The simultaneous doping for A- and B-sites of ABO3 cobaltites is a good choice for balancing numerous functional properties. Examples of such cobaltites include Ba1– x Sr x Co1– y Fe y O3– δ (BSCF) and La1– x Sr x Co1– y Fe y O3– δ (LSCF). In addition to cobaltites with a single perovskite structure, double perovskites such as LnBaCo2O5+ δ , Ba2CoMo0.5Nb0.5O5+ δ , and Ba2Co1.7Bi0.1Sr0.2O5+ δ are also considered as promising electrode materials (crystal lattices of both perovskite structures mentioned are shown schematically in Fig. 5 a). The next section will present their properties. 5.2 Layered cobaltites Cobaltites with a double perovskite structure are derivatives of simple ABO3 perovskite structure, in which oxygen vacancy ordering occurs due to structural peculiarities, including a specific combination of valences, ionic radii, and concentrations of basic cations. Principally, A-site (AA'B2O5+ δ ) or B-site (A2BB'O5+ δ ) ordering is possible. However, a large family of cobaltites belongs to the former cases, LnBaCo2O5+ δ , where Ln is the lanthanides or yttrium. The layered structure of LnBaCo2O5+ δ can be simply represented as a sequence of CoO2|LnO δ |CoO2|BaO motifs, where the disordered CoO2 octahedra are sandwiched by alternating LnO and BaO layers, resulting in the A-site ordering [150]. LnBaCo2O5+ δ can be crystallized in various structures, including orthorhombic, tetragonal, or cubic ones, depending on the nature of Ln3+ as well nature and concentration of introduced dopants. The specific structure is determined by the oxygen stoichiometry (δ), which can range from 0 to 1. Therefore, the LnBaCo2O5+ δ compositions are often represented as LnBaCo2O6– δ . They exhibit very high total electronic conductivity (ranging from 100 to 1000 S cm−1), high oxygen-ionic transport, and acceptable chemical compatibility with CeO2-, LSGM-, Ba(Ce,Zr)O3-based electrolytes. These advantages allow the application of LnBaCo2O5+ δ as oxygen electrodes for various electrochemical cells. One of their main drawbacks consists in high TECs, typically above 20·10–6 K−1. To address this issue, the substitution of Ba- and Co-sites is frequently employed. For example, Klyndyuk et al. [151] and Zheng et al. [152] provided an overview of double perovskites with particular emphasis on substituted derivatives. These works confirm that the substitutions of Ln3+ with smaller lanthanides, Ba2+ with calcium or strontium, and Co-ions with iron, nickel or copper are beneficial in terms of reduced TECs. Furthermore, single SOFCs with these electrodes exhibit high performance, regardless of the electrolytes used. 5.3 Cobaltite-ferrites Cobaltite-ferrites with both simple and layered structures are considered as one of the most promising oxygen electrodes. For example, according to Scopus analysis, a number of publications on Ba1– x Sr x Co1– y Fe y O3– δ (BSCF) and La1– x Sr x Co1– y Fe y O3– δ (LSCF) exceed 1,200 and 3,100 items, respectively. From a BSCF system, the composition with x = 0.5, y = 0.2 [153] exhibits the highest oxygen-ionic conductivity, which is crucial for oxygen electrodes operating under ORR and OER modes [154]. It is interesting that the defect structure of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3– δ is highly sensitive to pre-history of the materials preparation: the δ value can range between 2.5 and 3.0 at room temperature and from ∼2.3 to 2.8 at 800–1000 °C, which affects many defect-related properties. The work of Sahini et al. [153] analyzes the synthesis features and various functional properties of Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3– δ , including thermochemical behavior, phase stability, mechanical properties, and electrochemical performance as oxygen-permeable membranes. Although possessing many advantageous properties, the material exhibits several issues, including high chemical expansion at temperatures higher than 500 °C, possible phase transition from the cubic Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3– δ structure to a hexagonal perovskite below 850 °C, insufficient chemical stability in the presence of CO2, and low ionic conductivity at temperatures below 650 °C. However, these problems can be eliminated by further doping BSCF with different types of dopants. Similar to the cobaltites mentioned earlier, the chemical stability of BSCF can be enhanced by introducing high valence cations (Nb5+, V5+, Ta5+, Sb5+, W6+), while its ionic conductivity can be adjusted by creating deficiencies or introducing certain 3d-elements, such as zinc, scandium, nickel, and copper. As shown above, the La1– x Sr x Co1– y Fe y O3– δ (LSCF) complex oxides have been extensively studied as SOFC and SOEC electrodes. These oxides were initially developed for the conventional zirconia electrolytes, but then successfully applied for the electrochemical cells based on other oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes. The LSCF materials exhibit lower TEC values (compared to those of BSCF), comparable oxygen-ionic conductivity, and better chemical stability in CO2 environment, all these features are beneficial in terms of realizing the high and stable electrochemically activity of the LSCF-derived electrodes [42,132]. However, LSCF as a representative of Sr-containing phases suffers from the strontium segregation that inhibits the surface-active sites for the ORR process. Several recent reviews provide a detailed analysis of this problem and its potential solutions [140,155]. Among cobaltite-ferrites with double perovskite structure, PrBa0.5Sr0.5Co1.5Fe0.5O5+ δ (PBSCF) has attracted much attention, especially for the protonic ceramic electrochemical cells. This material exhibits all advantages of electrochemically active electrodes coupled with possible proton uptake, resulting in so-called triple-conducting phases. Currently, there are no thematic reviews published on PBSCF. However, its properties have been well-analyzed in articles dedicated to triple-conducting phases, see Section 5.8. 5.4 Fe-based perovskites Iron-based perovskites have recently gained attention as electrode components that operate efficiently in both oxidizing and reducing atmospheres. Indeed, ferrites of various compositions can be used in so-called symmetric solid oxide electrochemical cells due to their excellent redox activity over a wide range of electrode functions. Although there are a large number of reviews devoted to symmetric electrodes of SOFCs or SOECs [156–163], only a few papers describe the structural and functional properties of specific ferrite families, including doped SrFeO3 [164], doped BaFeO3 [165], doped LaFeO3 [166]. According to these comprehensive reviews, all of the basic families can be used to design both fuel and oxygen electrode materials. Regarding the latter, BaFeO3, (La,Sr)FeO3, (Sm,Sr)FeO3 are the most investigated phases. Usually, such complex oxides have some limitations, which can be related to different aspects: for example, low chemical stability or insufficient electrochemical (electrocatalytic) activity. Therefore, these phases are often modernized by doping/codoping. For example, the iron substitution with stable valence dopants (Zn2+, Sc3+, Ti4+, Zr4+, Nb5+, Mo6+, W6+) improves the chemical stability of ferrites, while iron substitution with nickel or copper can improve the electrochemical activity and reduce the TEC values. A reduction of the undesirable chemical expansion of ferrites, which occurs at the high temperature range, can be achieved through A-site doping. This involves partially substituting barium or lanthanides with low ionic radius dopants such as strontium or small-sized lanthanides. 5.5 Layered nickelate materials The oxide materials of Ln2NiO4+ δ (where Ln = La, Nd, and Pr) have a layered structure and belong to a Ruddlesden–Popper (RP) family with the general formula of A n +1B n O3 n +1, where n ≥ 1 [131,147,167–170]. The layered structure of A n +1B n O3 n +1 can be represented as a repeated sequence of perovskite-type (ABO3) n blocks and rock salt AO motive, i.e., AO(ABO3) n . Fig. 5 (a) presents crystal structure schemes for RP phases of A n +1B n O3 n +1 with n values of 1, 2, and 3. Considering a general formula of Ln2NiO4+ δ , it belongs to the first member of homologous RP-type nickelate series together with further members of Ln3Ni2O7 and Ln4Ni3O10. Nickelates are known as complex oxide materials with very low TEC values (around (12–15)×10–6 K−1), high oxygen diffusion and surface exchange coefficients (at 600 °C, around 5×10–8 cm2 s−1 and 5×10–7 cm s−1, respectively), and, correspondingly, high oxygen ionic conductivity (up to 100 mS cm−1 at 800 °C) [171]. These features allow them to be considered as promising oxygen electrodes for both oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes. A comprehensive review of Tarutin et al. [171] provides an in-depth analysis of the Ln2NiO4+ δ materials as well as their structural and functional properties depending on different doping approaches. Special emphasis was given to the application of Ln2NiO4+ δ -based electrodes in protonic ceramic electrochemical cells. For example, power densities of 500 mW cm−2 and higher can be obtained for PCFCs at 600 °C due to excellent electrochemical activity of the nickelates, when the polarization resistance of PCFC electrodes achieves 0.3–0.5 Ω cm2 at the same temperature. Ding et al. [172] reviewed the same materials not only as electrodes for PCFCs or PCECs, but also as electrodes for SOFCs and SOECs based on oxygen-ionic electrolytes. A focus review of Pikalova et al. [173] demonstrated the advantages and drawbacks of the Ln-substituted La2NiO4+ δ for application in solid oxide fuel and electrolysis cells, compared to the non-substituted La2NiO4+ δ . In the work of Morales-Zapata et al. [174], the material selection and electrochemical performance of nickelates were reviewed with special emphasis on their thermal expansion coefficients, kinetic parameters, and polarization resistances. Generally, these reviews confirm the high potential of Ln2NiO4+ δ -based materials as possible electrodes for various electrochemical cells. 5.6 High-entropy oxides The use of high entropy oxides (HEOs), which contain five or more cations in a crystallographic position at near equimolar concentrations (Fig. 5a), as potential air electrodes are justified by their excellent long-term durability due to the enhancement of the functional properties of HEOs compared to the conventional compounds. Pikalova et al. [175] and Liu et al. [176] reviewed the stabilization mechanisms, preparation methods, structural and microstructural characterization, primary crystal structures, and leading directions in the development of HEOs for SOFCs operating in the low- and intermediate-temperature ranges. The reviews above suggest that LaMnO3-based HEO materials with disordered cations (such as La, Nd, Sm, Ca, and Sr) in the A-position demonstrate significant resistance to specific elemental consistencies. They also exhibit excellent chemical compatibility with the YSZ electrolyte (up to 1400 °C) and similar electrical conductivity values compared to those of conventional Sr-doped LaMnO3 (approximately 200 S cm−1 at 800 °C). The review [175] provides a summary of the performance of SOFCs with cathodes based on HEOs. It is shown that the perovskite La0.2Sr0.2Pr0.2Y0.2Ba0.2Co0.2Fe0.8O3– δ electrode on the YSZ electrolyte and the spinel Fe0.6Mn0.6Co0.6Ni0.6Cr0.6O4– δ electrode on the BCZY electrolyte have recently achieved outstanding electrochemical performance. The SOFCs with perovskite- and spinel-based electrodes demonstrate the highest power density values, reaching approximately 1000 mW cm−2 at 750 °C and 1050 mW cm−2 at 700 °C, respectively. The superior performance of the perovskite-based high electron output (HEO) electrode is attributed to the suppression of Sr-segregation and the improved chemical compatibility between the electrode and electrolyte materials. The spinel-based HEO electrode exhibits excellent performance due to its superior catalytic activity in ORR compared to the undoped Mn1.6Cu1.4O4 spinel. Another referenced review [176] provides detailed descriptions of the catalytic processes involved in OER and ORR in electrochemical devices using HEOs. According to the work [175], HEO electrodes based on LSCF have gained attention due to their improved Cr-tolerance. The highest MPD value (approximately 1000 mW cm−2 at 700 °C) among cells with similar construction was observed in a single cell composed of NiO-YSZ|YSZ|GDC|LSPYB with the HEO cathode (LSPYB) with disordered cations (La, Sr, Pr, Y, Ba) in the LSCF A-site. Additionally, the cell degradation was extremely low at 0.25% per 1 kh while operating for 41 days in the presence of Cr. The reviews [175–177] have concluded that the high electrochemical performance of HEOs as preferred air electrodes for SOFC is attributed to the specific design of high-entropy perovskites, which results in an increased content of oxygen vacancies. Gonçalves and Ruiz-Montoya [178] described a new family of high-entropy materials, named as high-entropy coordination compounds (HE-CCs), which could be used for designing electrode materials in the future. The authors also observed the synthesis of HE-CCs and their performance in catalyzing the hydrogen evolution reaction and oxygen evolution reaction in water electrolysis. 5.7 Fluorine-containing oxides Fluorine doping (Fig. 5a) has emerged as a promising approach to tailor the functional properties of complex oxide materials. Typically, complex oxides are modified through cationic-type doping, where impurity cations replace basic cations. While this strategy improves some properties, it can also degrade others due to significant changes in the cationic framework of a crystal. Anionic-type doping is a potential alternative route that leaves the cationic sites unchanged. This approach may be suitable for achieving a balance between various properties. According to existing reviews [179,180], the anionic-doping has been used for a number of SOFC/SOEC electrolyte and electrode materials. Many of these results have shown that the F-to-O substitution has two beneficial effects on the obtained materials, including their improved chemical stability and enhanced ionic mobility. As a result, the F-containing electrodes prevail over their F-free counterparts in terms of electrochemical and electrocatalytic activity. However, there are important issues related to: (1) the actual content in such materials due to the possible removal of fluorine during synthesis or operation at high temperatures, (2) the understanding of the mechanisms underlying oxygen ion migration affected by anion doping. 5.8 Triple-conducting oxides Triple-conducting oxides (TCOs) belong to a distinct group of complex oxide materials that can provide three types of charge carriers: electrons or holes, oxygen-ions, and protons. Barium cerate and barium zirconate are examples of classical proton-conducting materials that are also triple-conducting phases since they can exhibit all three conducting behaviors under specific conditions [39]. However, electrode materials are often attributed with TCOs due to their enhanced electrochemical activity during PCFC/PCEC operation compared to classical MIEC examples with dual conducting behavior (oxygen-ionic/electronic or protonic/electronic). TCOs can be obtained as derivatives from conventional proton-conducting perovskites (BaCeO3, BaZrO3) via their doping with transition 3d-elements in high amounts [45]. In this way, the as-doped compounds retain their crystal structure and crystallochemical features allowing the realization of proton conductivity. Such examples are single-phase and dual phase compounds with nominal Ba(Ce,Zr)(MM')O3– δ compositions, where M is the 3d-element with variable valency (M = Fe, Co) to achieve high MIEC transport, M' is the acceptor dopant creating oxygen vacancies (M' = Y, Yb, Sc) to achieve high protonic transport. Among these derivatives, BaCo0.4Fe0.4Zr0.2O3– δ and its doped products (BaCo0.4Fe0.4Zr0.1Y0.1O3– δ , BaCo0.4Fe0.4Zr0.1Sc0.1O3– δ , BaCo0.4Fe0.4Zr0.2– x Y x O3– δ , labeled as BCFZ and BCFZY) can be recognized as one of the most promising TCOs [105,106,181]. Indeed, the related electrodes exhibit very high electrochemical activity under PCFC and PCEC operation in wet atmosphere environment. Other promising TCO classes are double cobaltites (mainly PrBa0.5Sr0.5Co1.5Fe0.5O5+ δ , PBSCF) and layered nickelates (based on Ln2NiO4+ δ ), which are also widely studied for various protonic ceramic electrochemical cells. While TCOs exhibit excellent polarization activity towards ORR and OER, they suffer from high TEC values [45] due to the high concentration of transition elements, particularly for BCFZ, BCFZY, and PBSCF. Additionally, their long-term stability under direct operating conditions remains unclear and requires further investigation. 5.9 Composite materials While single-phase materials can demonstrate specific desirable functions for certain applications, achieving a balance between all necessary functional properties is often challenging when using single doping, co-doping, or multi-doping strategies. In this respect, the researchers propose composite materials, when two or three components of such mixtures simultaneously satisfy all necessary properties (Fig. 5 b). Aziz et al. [127], Mather et al. [47], Yi et al. [182], and Long et al. [183] provide comprehensive analysis on the progress and prospects of oxygen electrode composites for solid oxide electrochemical cells based on both oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes. According to these reviews, composite cathodes combine the advantages over single-phase oxides, weaken the deficiencies of the latter. In detail, composites have lower TEC values due to the presence of an electrolytic component and extended electrochemical active sites resulting from different MIEC, ionic, or triple-conducting pathways for each component. Along with dual- or multi-phase mechanical mixtures, other hierarchical structures (heterostructure composites, core–shell composites, as shown in Fig. 5b) are of great interest as well [184–188]. Although these types of composites have advantages, their stability and chemical compatibility of constituent phases pose significant long-term challenges, which limit their large-scale applications. 5.10 Research activity in oxygen electrode materials As can be seen from Section 5, oxygen electrodes are one of the most studied functional materials for various solid oxide electrochemical cells. This fact is associated with the necessary of searching for compositions exhibiting excellent electrochemical and electrocatalytic activities towards ORR and OER processes at reduced operating temperatures. According to Fig. S2, more than 1000 articles related to oxygen electrodes are published annually, showing actually wide variety in design, experimental characterization, theoretical forecasting, and improvements for both already known and new oxygen electrodes. 6 Fuel electrodes Fuel electrode materials are no less important for solid oxide electrochemical cells than electrolyte or oxygen electrode functional materials. These electrodes perform several vital functions associated with fuel oxidation (for SOFCs) or fuel production (for SOECs) and accompanying electron transfer, thus completing the second half of the reaction. Similar to oxygen electrodes, fuel electrodes are porous objects with high gas permeability. However, fuel electrodes must meet specific requirements when operating under highly reduced atmospheric conditions. (1) High electrochemical activity towards fuel oxidation (for SOFCs) and flexibility of fuel production (for SOECs). The possible fuels to be oxidized include not only hydrogen, but also CO [189], NH3 [190–193], methane [194,195] or other hydrocarbons [196–200], carbon [201–204], biomass [205]. In addition, the following components can be subject to the electrolysis process: H2O [52,206–208], CO2 [209–213], H2O + CO2 [214–216]. (2) High electronic conductivity is required along with adequate ionic conductivity to expand the electrochemical active area and number of triple phase boundaries. Fuel electrodes can be composite systems, consisting of an electronic conductor and an ionic conductor, or single complex oxide phases with high mixed ionic-electronic conductivity. (3) Well-developed pore structure, which is essential in facilitating high gas permeability and the facile transportation of fuels to the electrode/electrolyte interface, while allowing for the effective removal of reactants from this interface at the same time. (4) Microstructural stability in terms of maintaining the origin quality of particles with their low sintering or coarsening during long-term operation [217]. (5) Mechanical stability, especially in the anode-supported configuration. (6) Thermal and mechanical compatibility with other functional components to avoid the formation of low conductive interphase phases and high mechanical stress during thermal cycling. (7) High chemical stability against various sources of poisoning [218–221] and carbon deposition [222–224]. As can be seen, these are strict requirements that are difficult to meet simultaneously. Consequently, many reasons cause degradation processes related to fuel electrodes [225–228]. Therefore, rational material design of these materials is of great importance. 6.1 Conventional Ni-based cermets The first SOFCs and SOECs were initially made of platinum for both the fuel and oxygen electrodes. However, their performance was limited due to a lack of active sites for electrochemical reactions. Due to the high cost of noble metals, research has shifted its focus towards Ni-based compounds. Nickel is often combined with a component that offers ionic conductivity (for example, Ni–YSZ, Ni–SDC, Ni–BCZYYb) to extend considerably electrochemically active sites. However, Ni-based ceramic-metallics (as-called cermets) face several serious issues, including nickel oxidation, nickel coarsening during prolonged high-temperature operation, and coking. These issues result in the degradation of fuel electrodes and the entire electrochemical cells. Several review articles [197,217,229] discuss the historical activity, the mentioned problems, recent achievements, and prospects of such cermets. Shabri et al. [197] analyzed the prospects of using metal-ceramic SOFC anodes. They explained the causes of carbon deposition and presented potential strategies to overcome this issue for cermets. In terms of materials design, both components of the conventional Ni–YSZ cermets can be modified. The metallic part can be replaced by bimetallic or metallic alloy electrocatalyst analogs (Ni–Cu, Ni–Fe, Ni–Pd, Ni–Ru). This substitution has been found to be advantageous for deeper conversion of C-containing products without coking. SDC- or GDC-based components can replace the electrolytic YSZ part. As was mentioned in Section 4.1.2, ceria compounds exhibit a mixed ionic-electronic conductivity behavior, thereby extending the triple phase boundary. Liu et al. [229] provide a thorough overview of nickel-based cermet anode materials, covering various aspects related to these materials. In detail, an analysis was conducted on: (1) the technological features of powder preparation and the fabrication of Ni-based supported anodes, (2) the microstructural properties of composite anodes and their long-term degradation, (3) the main functional properties, including total conductivity and thermal expansion behavior, (4) the mechanism behind carbon deposition and sulfur poisoning, as well as possible strategies to improve chemical stability, and finally, (5) new strategies for anode design. Furthermore, Vafaeenezhad et al. [217] examine the microstructural parameters of Ni-based anodes, including their changes depending on the synthesis prehistory and their behavior during long-term operation. 6.2 Simple perovskites Ni-based cermets, which are two-phase or multi-phase composites, are the most widely used for various solid oxide electrochemical cells. However, they have some drawbacks, such as coarsening of metallic parts, poor coking tolerance, and possible sulfur poisoning. Therefore, alternative candidates for fuel electrodes are being sought. Complex oxides with a simple perovskite structure can be considered as such candidates if they have sufficient chemical stability in highly reducing environments as well as high mixed ionic-electronic conductivity. Recently, several families of fuel electrodes have been proposed, including doped (La,Sr)TiO3, (La,Sr)(Ti,Fe)O3, (La,Sr)(Mn,Fe)O3, (La,Sr)(Mn,Cr)O3, and (La,Sr)CrO3. Perovskites containing redox active elements such as titanium, iron, manganese, and chromium can regulate electronic conductivity by changing their oxidation state without decomposing the perovskite structure. The A-site of these perovskites often contains a combination of lanthanum and strontium, which governs their chemical stability and oxygen transport properties. Although no specific reviews on these systems have been published, information about them can be found in several general reviews [203,222,223,230–233]. 6.3 Double perovskites Double perovskite materials with both A-site ordering or B-site (AA'B2O5+ δ , A2BB'O5+ δ ) are considered as promising alternatives to conventional composite Ni-cermet systems due to their favorable functional properties for use as fuel (hydrogen) electrodes. Ahmed et al. [234] provide a brief overview of potential candidates among a group of double perovskite materials (Sr2MgMoO6– δ , Sr2CoMoO6– δ , Sr2NiMoO6– δ , Sr2FeMoO6– δ , PrBaMn2O6– δ , and PrBaFe2O6– δ ) as well as their functional properties. Their analysis shows that molybdates exhibit better conductivity (from 5 to 60 S cm−1) and polarization resistance (0.1–0.3 Ω cm2) values compared to those for the A-site ordered ferrites or manganites (0.5–10 S cm−1 and 0.1–0.3 Ω cm2, respectively), all data are provided at 800 °C. Despite these differences, the SOFCs based on both A- or B-site ordered double perovskites yield high power densities (from 100 to 1500 mW cm−2 at 800 °C), when hydrogen or methane was used as a fuel). Skutina et al. [235] present a comprehensive overview of undoped Sr2MgMoO6– δ , Sr2NiMoO6– δ , Sr2FeMoO6– δ , and Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ molybdates and compare their potential as fuel electrodes based on their synthesis features, chemical stability, thermal expansion coefficients, and conductivity in both oxidizing and reducing conditions. Double perovskites (Sr2MMoO6– δ ) exhibit a modified perovskite structure (ABO3), where the BO6 and MoO6 octahedra are located in two alternating face-centered cubic sublattices with a space group of Fm3m (or Pm3m), as shown in Fig. 6 (a). The cubic structure typically experiences deformation because of an ionic radii mismatch between the Sr-, M-, and Mo-cations, producing the most energy-efficient configuration. When the BO6 and MoO6 octahedra rotate relative to each other at an angle determined by the displacement of oxygen atoms within the ab plane, the tetragonal lattice achieves greater stability, Fig. 6(b). Additionally, the double perovskite structure may exhibit reduced symmetry due to octahedra tilting (see Fig. 6c). Such cases can result in the formation of monoclinic (a ≠ b ≠ c, α = β = 90°, γ ≠ 90°), triclinic (a ≠ b ≠ c, α ≠ β ≠ γ ≠ 90°), or even orthorhombic (a ≠ b ≠ c, α = β = γ = 90°) polymorph modifications. Among the considered basic oxides, Sr2MgMoO6– δ , Sr2NiMoO6– δ , Sr2FeMoO6– δ , and Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ , the latter is one of the most promising [235]. In detail, Sr2MgMoO6– δ is thermodynamically unstable in the air conditions necessary for materials synthesis and electrolyte co-sintering, while Sr2NiMoO6– δ decomposes under reducing environments, Sr2FeMoO6– δ exhibits very high electronic conductivity in hydrogen atmospheres, but its chemical stability in oxidizing regions remains unclear. In this regard, Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ displays high electronic conductivity in both oxidizing and reducing atmospheres, good compatibility with LSGM and ceria electrolytes and exceptional chemical stability when exposed to C-based fuels and even H2S. These findings are supported by Suchaneck and Artiukh's review [236]. In detail, Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ is the optimal composition among the Sr2Fe1+ x Mo1– x O6– δ series. Therefore, Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ has become a highly studied functional material with about research 100 publications since 2019, including three recent reviews of Zhang et al. [237], Porotnikova and Osinkin [238], and Qiu et al. [239]. These reviews describe the recent achievements and further prospects of the origin and variously doped Sr2Fe1.5Mo0.5O6– δ compounds as fuel electrodes for SOFCs and SOECs operating with hydrogen and carbon-based gases. 6.4 Symmetrical (quasi-symmetrical) electrodes Symmetrical electrodes for SOFCs, SOECs, PCFCs, and PCECs require materials that exhibit satisfactory stability in both oxidizing and reducing conditions, as well as other necessary functional properties such as compatibility, thermal expansion, ionic and electronic conductivity, and electrochemical activity that are suitable for the intended applications.
