Several recent reviews have highlighted the fundamental and technological aspects of electrochemical cells with symmetrically organized electrodes [156–163]. 6.5 Research activity in fuel electrode materials Fuel electrode materials are extensively researched due to their use as supported functional layers for SOFCs and SOECs based on both oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes. Research activities on fuel electrodes are shown to be equally important as those dealing with oxygen electrodes, as demonstrated in Fig. S3. This highlights the significance of fuel electrodes in processes related to fuel conversion. From the brief information given in Section 6, it is clear that the simple and double perovskites are alternatives to the conventional Ni-cermet electrodes, with a high applied potential. However, their real application in SOFCs and SOECs is still limited by several problems. These include low redox stability of the complex oxides during their synthesis/sintering in air and real operation in reducing atmospheres, considerable chemical expansion effects associated with the variation of pO2 by 15–20 orders of magnitude (air/wet H2), and insufficient electrochemical activity with respect to fuel oxidation. Many research groups are currently working to address these issues, using both theoretical and empirical approaches to design such complex oxide materials. 7 Other SOFC/SOEC functional materials Three main components (electrolyte, oxygen electrode, and fuel electrode) form the basis of SOFCs and SOECs, which can be successfully fabricated and tested on a laboratory scale to evaluate the performance of the materials used. However, scaling up the individual electrochemical cells is necessary to increase overall performance. In this regard, many such cells are used together in the form of stacks, which represent a multiple repetition of sandwich-like structures. It is obvious that a larger-scale device requires additional functional materials that play a crucial role, such as interconnects, glass sealants, coatings, and protective layers. This section provides a brief discussion of their functions and properties. 7.1 Interconnects and coatings Historically, high-temperature SOFCs have used ceramic interconnects such as LaCrO3, due to their acceptable properties in terms of high electronic conductivity and reasonable thermal expansion coefficients. However, to improve mechanical compatibility and electrochemical performance, the focus has further shifted to Ni- and Cr-based steels such as Crofer 22A/APU/H, Alloy 310 austenitic steels, Haynes 230 and others. To ensure the long-term durability of stainless steels as interconnects in SOCs, it is necessary to meet the following key requirements [240]. • Resistance to oxidation and corrosion, • High conductivity of the oxide layer and low resistive loss, • No reactivity between alloy and oxide with other SOC materials, • Matching of TEC with ones for other SOC parts. From an experimental viewpoint, an amount of 18–22 wt.% chromium is considered to be optimal to achieve protective properties of steels in oxidizing conditions at elevated temperatures and acceptable ohmic resistance [241]. Nevertheless, the long-term operation inevitably results in the so-called chromium poisoning of the oxygen electrodes, being one of the main degradation factors. The use of interconnect coatings can suppress these undesirable effects by forming a dense and continuous coating layer. In this regard, interconnects and coatings are inextricably linked pairs of materials, which are analyzed together in several review articles. Mao et al. [240] and Zhu et al. [242] provided an overview of typical protective materials (spinels, perovskites, La, Y, Ce, Zr oxides) that could be used as coatings for metallic interconnects in SOFCs. Various coating deposition methods have been observed and analyzed, including electrophoresis, electroplating, electrophoretic deposition/electroplating, magnetron sputtering, pulsed laser deposition, electron beam evaporation, screen printing, sol–gel coating, and plasma spraying. Hu et al. [243] focused on techniques to improve the coating quality by discussing the influence of dynamic processes on the deposition behavior of charged metal oxide particles. The reviews [244,245] summarized the recent articles on commonly used coatings, such as (Mn,Cu)3O4 and (Mn,Co)3O4 spinels, and considered the correlation between their physical and chemical properties, fabrication and deposition technologies, characterization and performance. It was concluded that the overall coating performance depends more on the spinel composition, quality, and thickness of the coating than on the deposition technique. Hassan et al. [246] reported that interconnects with Cu-Fe based spinel coatings, such as SUS-430, showed equivalent performance to Crofer 22 APU with Mn-Co based spinel coating. This suggests that SUS-430 interconnects could replace conventional interconnects due to their lower cost. 7.2 Metal supporting layers Conventional SOFCs and SOECs are commonly designed with an anode-supported configuration, where a nickel-based cermet layer determines the mechanical quality of the entire multilayered cell. However, metal-supported electrochemical cells have gained significant interest due to their advantages over anode-supported cells, including lower metal costs, faster startup, easier manufacturing, and greater mechanical stability. Metal-supported cells can be designed in various ways (including planar, tubular, and flat-tubular) and can use different components for their metal support layers, such as ferritic stainless steels, nickel alloys, SS-430L alloys, Croffer 22APU, and others. Despite promising results for metal-supported SOFCs and SOECs [247–252], they still experience serious issues related to rapid degradation. The previous section extensively discussed two main challenges: the high-temperature oxidation of metals or alloys being used, and the issues of carbon deposition and chromium poisoning. 7.3 Glass sealants High-temperature glasses are key components of SOFC and SOEC technology as they act as a sealant between different functional materials on one side as well as prevent anode and cathode gas mixing on the other side. Glass sealants constitute a part of the ‘know-how’ for real commercialization of SOFCs and SOECs. Despite significant research on glass sealants, only about 1000 related publications have been indexed in the Scopus database to date, with only two review papers published since 2020 [253,254]. The glass sealant must meet several strict requirements, which are briefly outlined below. • High chemical and thermal compatibilities with electrolyte, coating, and interconnector materials. • Thermal and cycling stability coupled with high resistance towards thermal shocks. • Chemical stability in terms of phase and microstructural properties as well as related functional properties in long-term perspective (10–50 kh). • Low conductivity to prevent any electrochemical reactions at the glass-based interfaces. • High hermeticity to ensure the gas-tightness of the entire multilayered system, consisting of ceramic, cermet, metallic components. • Simple application, manufacturing, and processing stages. • Low costs. A review work of Singh and Walia [253] provides the recent progress and development in the field of glass sealants and proposes potential research avenues for continued improvement in this field. The authors focused their attention on silicate and borosilicate glass sealant, providing their basic properties (including thermal expansion coefficient, glass transition temperature, crystalline temperature, and melting temperature values) depending on composition variations, i.e., glass network former, network modifier, and intermediate nucleating agents. In detail, silicate and borosilicate glass sealants containing alkaline and alkaline-earth, and rare-earth elements, were reviewed. Tulyaganov et al. [254] present an in-depth analysis regarding the functional properties of glass–ceramic sealants, using a CaO–MgO–SiO2 system as an example. The authors analyze the phase diagrams in multicomponent oxide systems and indicate which ceramic phases can be formed from an amorphous glass phase. Although these glass–ceramic sealants can be used for biomedical and nuclear waste immobilization applications, part of the review is also aimed at high-temperature applications, highlighting existing research activities in the use of CaO–MgO–SiO2 sealants in SOFCs. The proposed system shows promise for the development of effective glass sealants, but its long-term stability requires further experimental verification. 7.4 Protecting ceramic interlayers Conventional SOFCs and SOECs utilize zirconia-based electrolytes in combination with various electrode systems composed of rare-earth or alkaline-earth elements. According to numerous studies, long-term treatment of such electrolyte/electrode pairs at high temperatures results in the formation of insulating phases (such as La2Zr2O7, SrZrO3) with an ionic conductivity of several times lower than that of stabilized zirconia electrolytes. The appearance of high ohmic resistance is mainly caused by the low conductive phase formed at the interface as a result of such interaction. This significantly degrades the performance of SOFCs and SOECs, even if they are made of good functional materials. In this regard, many researchers utilize ceria-based interlayers placed between the zirconia-based electrolytes and electrodes, these interlayers act as protective, buffering, or blocking layers, improving the chemical compatibility properties between various functional materials. Several reviews highlight the prospects and achievements of ceria-based protecting interlayers to ensure the long-term stability of solid oxide electrochemical systems [60–62,255]. Khan et al. [60] presented a detailed review of the importance of using ceria interlayers and their stability in preventing cross-migration and interdiffusion during the production and operation of SOFCs and SOECs. The study identified several factors that contribute to interdiffusion processes, including the microstructural parameters of functional materials, lattice strain, temperature, polarization, and gas environment. Additionally, the effects of cross-migration and interdiffusion on the SOFC and SOEC performance have been thoroughly studied. The analysis of literature data enables the authors to suggest several approaches to regulate the undesirable cationic migration and interdiffusion. These include fabricating dense ceria interlayers at low sintering temperatures and using Sr-free electrode materials. He and Jiang [255] analyzed the interface chemistry between anode/electrolyte and cathode/electrolyte pairs under actual operating conditions of solid oxide electrochemical cells (high temperatures, cathodic/anodic polarizations, gas atmospheres). They extensively discussed the possible relationships between cell performance and interface phenomena, such as element segregation, impurity contamination, micropore formation, and interfacial reaction. Furthermore, they provide useful information regarding qualitative and quantitative analysis of the interfaces, listing possible characterization techniques along with their advantages and limitations. These techniques include focused ion beam analysis coupled with scanning transmission electron microscopy, 3D modeling or secondary ion mass spectroscopy analyses, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy, X-ray nano-computed tomography, atomic force microscopy. Sahini and Lupyana [61] also considered the causes of interdiffusion processes in SOFCs and SOECs and proposed possible solutions for mitigating their negative effects. To achieve strong and reliable device performance, several measures for controlling cationic cross-diffusion have been recommended: using diffusion barriers between electrodes, creating cathode materials without strontium, lowering the sintering and operating temperatures of SOFCs, and utilizing a rational materials selection. As can be seen, these solutions align with those presented in previous research. Erpalov et al. [62] presented a comprehensive review focused on CeO2-based interlayers for ZrO2-, LaGaO3-, and Ba(Ce,Zr)O3-based SOFCs and SOECs. In this work, the authors offer a historical overview of chemical compatibility issues occurring for classical YSZ/LSM couples and detrimental properties of La2Zr2O7 and SrZrO3 interaction phases. Considering the ceria interlayers, a special emphasis was given to basic properties of doped CeO2 materials, early practice of using bi-layered electrolytes, current trends in ceria protecting layers for electrochemical cells based on oxygen-ionic and proton-conducting electrolytes, limitations of CeO2-based protecting layers, and variations in utilizing CeO2-based layer compositions. In addition, SOFC and SOEC performance was thoroughly linked with quality of ceria interlayers. According to the mentioned reviews, to achieve optimal long-term performance of solid oxide electrochemical devices, it is necessary to address certain chemical compatibility issues. Considering the historical aspect of these issues, the conventional zirconia electrolytes (YSZ, ScSZ) and Sr-containing electrodes (LSM, LSC, LSF, etc.) have been widely used. However, at high temperatures, their combined operation produces impurity phases (such as La2Zr2O7 and SrZrO3) at the interface between the electrolyte and electrode. Since impurities naturally have low ionic conductivity, they worsen the efficiency and performance of SOFC/SOEC, and contribute to cell failure due to thermomechanical stress (see Fig. 7 a). The use of doped ceria interlayers is a vital technological solution for supressing the active interaction of the functional materials mentioned above. However, if the interlayers are made in a porous form, SrZrO3 may still accumulate at the electrolyte/interlayer interface (Fig. 7b) due to the high diffusion of Sr2+ through the interface surface, grain boundaries, and even pores. Furthermore, when there are disconnections between the electrolyte and the interlayer, high ohmic losses occur due to the limited oxygen-conducting sites at the interface. These issues can be resolved by using dense interlayers with fewer grain boundaries (Fig. 7c). In detail, the experimental results indicate that impurity phases are not formed in such cases. The following breakthrough is related to reducing the thickness of interlayers while maintaining their dense state. SOFCs and SOECs fabricated in this way exhibit outstanding performance parameters in both the short and long term focuses (Fig. 7d). Nonetheless, to produce such superior interlayers, cost-effective, convenient, and scalable manufacturing techniques must be employed. Compared to oxygen-ionic electrolytes, the interface processes for proton-conducting electrolyte systems seem to be more complicated due to an additional sort of charge carriers (protons) and features of space charge layers within the grain boundaries. Tsvetkov et al. [256] overviewed possible improvements of the cathode/electrolyte and anode/electrolyte interfaces of PCFCs and PCECs. To improve the electrochemical activity of the interfaces, several highly effective approaches can be applied to both oxygen and fuel electrodes, including their surface functionalization, exsolution, infiltration, designing nanocomposites. These strategies allow the improvement of numerous functions, starting from greater electrochemical activity of the electrodes, lower ohmic resistance of the electrolyte and the interfaces, and improved carbon and sulfur-poisoning tolerance. Chiara et al. [257] considered grain boundaries and heterostructures within the proton-conducting electrolytes, the electrode/electrolyte contacts, and the interfaces within composite anode and cathode materials. Among various interesting results, the authors discuss the effect of sintering additives on the grain boundary transport, since the effect of nickel diffusion from the Ni-cermet electrode to the proton-conducting electrolytes is a well-documented process. The authors raised an important question of how to modify both the electrolyte and anode functional materials to suppress the negative effects of nickel cations on the electrolyte properties. 7.5 Research activity in other functional materials Fig. S4 shows that the functional materials discussed in Section 7 have attracted significant attention from researchers aiming to scale SOFC and SOEC technologies from laboratories to industrial levels. Metallic interconnects, glass sealants, coatings, and protective buffer layers are crucial in this regard. Despite their importance, there are fewer papers devoted to these functional materials compared to those related to electrolyte or electrode systems. The importance of the electrolyte and electrode materials in solid oxide electrochemical cells for experimental or theoretical research is evident. Other functional materials are necessary for fabricating enlarged stacks, which are a combination of single cells. 8 Mixed ionic-electronic conductors for dense ionic-permeable membranes Ionic- (mainly, oxygen) permeable membranes are of great interest in electrochemistry due to their ability to facilitate various gas separation and conversion processes at high temperatures with high selectivity and performance. These membranes are composed of single-phase or dual-phase (composite) materials that exhibit both ionic conductivity (caused by oxygen ions or protons) and electronic conductivity (caused by electrons or electron holes). The mixed ionic-electronic conducting (MIEC) membranes are driven by the chemical gradient of potential-determined components between the feed and permeate sides. The internal counter-diffusion of ionic and electronic charge carriers facilitates the electrochemical oxidation and reduction processes. This eliminates the need for anode/cathode layers and an internal electrical circuit to pass the current when using MIEC membranes. Since membrane separators or membrane reactors consist of a sole functional material, a MIEC membrane must adhere to stringent criteria. • High chemical stability at elevated temperatures and gas compositions at the feed and permeate sides, • High relative density to maintain the chemical potential gradient and to avoid non-electrochemical mixing of gases at the opposite membrane’s sides, • High ionic and electronic conductivity to achieve acceptable diffusion of charge carries across the dense membrane, • Low contribution of chemical expansion to avoid internal mechanical stresses between surface and bulk regions. • Good mechanical properties at both high temperatures and high temperature gradients (thermal expansion, fracture strength, elastic modulus, creep). Several review articles published since 2020 aim at the MIEC membranes. One of the most comprehensive reviews, published by Bai et al. in 2021 [258], thoroughly discusses the mechanisms of oxygen transport and rate-determining steps in oxygen permeation processes (see briefly in Fig. 8 a). The authors present an overview of the history and introduce various analytical models for analysing oxygen permeation parameters. These models include Wagner, Bouwmeester, Xu-Thomson, Tan and Li, Ghadimi, Van Hessel, and D-G models. Additionally, this work lists a wide range of materials suitable for use as MIEC membranes and their potential applications in processes such as oxygen separation and production, partial oxidation of methane, and oxidative coupling of methane. Chen et al. [44] presented a comprehensive roadmap dealing with promising MIEC membranes for different electrochemical processes. The roadmap covers conventional oxygen production/separation and hydrogen production/separation processes as well as more sophisticated (carbon-based) ones, such as CO2 separation, CO2 reduction, direct methane oxidative coupling. Along with the fundamental achievements, current applied-oriented activities coupled with techno-economic assessment were also analyzed. MIEC membranes are typically associated with oxygen production and separation processes [43,259,260]. However, the mode of operation depends on the materials used and experimental conditions such as temperature and gas components. In detail, Fig. 8(b) shows possible electrochemical scenarios for MIEC membranes, when the ionic conductivity is determined by either oxygen-ions (oxygen vacancies) or protons [41,259,261,262]. Although these unique processes have been experimentally confirmed and analyzed, there are several limitations that can also be identified. First, to produce hydrogen via water splitting using oxygen-ionic/electronic membranes, it is necessary to create a lower chemical activity of oxygen on the permeate side than that of H2O on the feed side. This can be achieved by using reducing gases (CO, CH4, H2) for their subsequent oxidation. The same occurs for CO2 reduction process regardless of the conducting behavior of MIEC membranes. Second, the C-based electrochemical conversion takes place with insufficient selectivity and conversion. For example, the oxidative coupling of methane is characterized by a C2-selectivity of 30%–90% and a CH4 conversion of 5%–50% depending on the type and design of membrane reactors [261]. Thirdly, only a few MIEC materials remain stable under both the feed and permeate atmospheres, including high amounts of steam, CO, CO2 or highly reducing conditions (dry H2, CO + H2, CH4, C2H6, C2H4, C2H2). Therefore, it is essential to make a rational selection of functional materials from the viewpoint of their chemical stability against carbonization, electrochemical poisoning, and decomposition. To address the latter issue, several review articles focus on the materials design and the modification of the membrane surfaces to improve both oxygen bulk diffusion and surface exchange coefficients [29,42,43,147,153,260,263,264], these works report performances of more than 500 different membrane and membrane reactors cells. The most promising MIEC membranes for oxygen separation processes are BSCF, LSCF, and PBSCF compositions with good kinetics parameters. Under reducing conditions, possible candidates for use in membrane reactors are doped BaFeO3– δ , Sr2FeMoO6– δ , and SrTiO3 compositions. 9 Methods for SOFC/SOEC fabrication, characterization, and control The reviews on the preparation of key components of SOC highlighted both methods for the improvement of materials, such as electrolytes [265–269], hetero- and nanostructured electrodes [266–273], anodes [232], and methods for the preparation and deposition of functional and intermediate layers [110–118,274–281]. Differences between the materials synthesis methods were successfully shown by Hadi et al. in [232]. The schemes of the selected methods including ball milling, co-precipitation, hydrothermal, template-based, solution combustion, and sol–gel, are presented in Fig. 9 (a). Among the other fabrication methods and deposition techniques used in SOC technology, combustion synthesis [282,283], wet synthesis [284], microwave heating [268], infiltration [271], flame-based synthesis [115], electric current-assisted sintering [285], interface regulation technology [286], compaction and molding [287], tape casting [275], dip casting [275], screen printing [274,275], 3D inkjet printing [280,288], binder jet printing [275], plasma spraying [267,275], spray pyrolysis [115,277], thermal spraying [289,290], magnetron sputtering [111,291], chemical vapor deposition [275], physical vapor deposition [111,275], pulsed laser deposition [117,279,292], electrophoretic deposition [116,243,275], electrolytic deposition [114], atomic layer deposition [278], electroless nickel co-deposition [275], electrospinning [270,276] could be mentioned. Fig. 9(b) shows the comparison between common-used thin-film deposition techniques. The potential of additive manufacturing (AM) technologies as a future route to the manufacture of SOEC and SOFC has been discussed by Zouridi et al. [288], Minary-Jolandan et al. [293], and Rasaki et al. [294]. There is a limited number of reviews that consider the application of research methods in SOC technology. Recent articles have discussed the use of X-ray absorption spectroscopy in the study of SOFCs and PCFCs [295,296]. The characterization and degradation mechanism of SOFC cathodes by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy has been highlighted [296,297]. The application of Raman spectroscopy [83,298], surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy [296,298], shell-isolated nanoparticle-enhanced Raman spectroscopy [298], transmission electron microscopy [296], scanning electron microscopy [296], electrochemical impedance spectroscopy [296], X-ray diffraction (XRD) [296] for the characterization of SOCs has also been reviewed. In addition, Massardo et al. [299] observed the influence of high pressure XRD on the design of the ceria electrolyte. In addition, relevant reviews have also considered control strategies such as proportional integral differential, adaptive, robust, model predictive, fuzzy logic, fault-tolerant, intelligent and observer-based approaches [300] as methods for determining characteristic parameters of SOFC systems with anode exhaust gas recirculation [301]. Furthermore, Yang et al. [302] provide a comprehensive overview of the latest meta-heuristic methods used for identifying SOFC parameters, while Zeng et al. [303] review studies on heat transfer in SOFCs and their corresponding control methods. 10 SOFC/SOEC operation and sustainability The electrochemical performance and stability of SOFCs have been researched extensively. This includes cells of different types and those operating on different fuels [55,304–306]. Peng et al. [305] presented pictures of SOFC performance evaluation and fault diagnosis, divided into major problem areas (as shown in Fig. 10 a and b). Addressing these issues would help achieve SOFC lifetime targets and reduce operational costs. The reviews [39,138,307] considered the correlation between cells performance and mass transport (mobility of ions, electrons, and protons, oxygen heteroexchange). Additionally, the reviews [136,137,308–310] provided insight into the research background for reversible solid oxide fuel cells (rSOCs), covering topics such as stack optimization design [308], electrochemical operation and electrocatalytic mechanism [136,309], and degradation issues [137,310]. To assess the overall performance of SOFCs, Noviyanti et al. [311] discussed the figure-of-merit compatibility of SOFC cells. The reviews [225,312–314] summarized the recent research on the SOFC degradation and failure diagnosis. The degradation mechanisms, influencing factors and perspectives for the future development were reviewed for metal-supported oxide cells [248,249], and for PCECs [226,315]. Wang et al. [227] and Xu et al. [316] summarized the technological limitations based on typical degradation phenomena of SOECs. Degradation mechanisms due to the poisoning of SOFC components by chromium vapours have been considered in a number of reviews [221,317–319]. Wang et al. [218] have provided a comprehensive understanding of the sulfur poisoning behaviour of SOFC perovskite cathodes. Fig. 10(c) summarizes the main degradation mechanisms of SOFC components. The surface segregation of cations on air electrodes and the cation interdiffusion at the cathode/electrolyte interface are the most critical issues in the long-term operation of solid oxide cells (SOCs). The phenomenon of A-site segregation, especially, Sr-, at the electrode surfaces has been reviewed for LSM [140], LSCF [139,140,155], LSC [139] cathodes, while the B-site segregation (e.g., Co, Ni, Fe) has been mentioned in the work [139]. The review [60,61,320] summarized the phenomenon of cation interdiffusion at the cathode/electrolyte interface during the fabrication and performance of SOCs. The chemical reactivity between the components of SOCs also effects on their durability: interfacial phenomena at the electrode surfaces were summarized for the air electrodes by Li et al. [139] and for the fuel electrodes by Curi et al. [321]. Several reviews have examined the behaviour of the electrode/electrolyte interface [255,257,322]. Singh et al. [253] summarised the interactions of glass sealants with electrolyte and interconnect materials. Zhang et al. [320] emphasised the importance of chemical compatibility between electrode and electrolyte materials. Additionally, Yang et al. [136] investigated delamination between the oxygen electrode and the electrolyte. Advanced technologies have been reported for cathode surface modification [36], interdiffusion suppression [320], optimal interface engineering [185], and the design of high durability SOCs with control of interfacial phenomena [60]. It is important to note that several reviews have been dedicated to the development of various types of interfacial layers. These include current collector layers in microtubular SOFCs [241], contact layers between interconnects and electrodes [35], catalyst layers over nickel-based anodes for hydrocarbon-fueled SOFCs [196], electron-blocking layers at the ceria-doped electrolyte [65], and protective coatings for steel interconnectors [244]. A limited number of reviews have presented trends in fuel cell technologies in terms of their sustainability, both in the safe operation and life cycle assessment. Therefore, Wei et al. [323] provided an analysis of fuel cell safety (shown in Fig. 11 a) based on 890 relevant publications in the Web of Science database, while Subotić et al. [228] discussed how to safely operate SOFCs and SOECs in long-term real-world operating environments. In addition, this text highlights recent advancements in biomass valorisation using hydrothermal liquefaction [324] and catalysis [325], as well as advanced technologies for power generation [326] and removal of contaminants from syngas derived from biomass gasification in SOFC systems (as shown in Fig. 11b) [220]. Sarner et al. [327] described the potential recycling routes for SOFC stack components, Salim et al. [328] presented a comprehensive review of the sustainability of SOFCs using life cycle costing, life cycle assessment and social life cycle. Afroze et al. [329] highlighted the effectiveness and ecological nature of SOFCs, which could provide electricity to isolated hospitals and enclosed areas to help relieve the strain on the power grid during the COVID-19 pandemic situation. 11 SOFC/SOEC modeling and mechanisms The published reviews on the fabrication and electrochemical behavior of SOCs reflect recent, widely used numerical and computational studies. A summary of recent achievements in machine learning-based approaches to the development of energy storage devices is also included [330,331]. Mathematical models of the SOFC [332–334], direct internal reforming SOFC [335], DMFC [333], PEMFC [333,334], SOFC components [141,336,337], internal short-circuit free ceria-based SOFC [65], SOEC performance evolution and material degradation [338,339], NH3 decomposition in SOFCs and membrane reactors [340], fuel recirculation for SOFC and PEMFC [341], porous media in engineering systems [342] have been overviewed. Computational approaches based on density functional theory (DFT) have been used to model the behavior of SOFC and (La,Sr)MnO3 cathodes [343], and to calculate the contribution of oxygen vacancies to the electrochemical reaction rate on different electrode surfaces [344], see Fig. 12 (a). Dhanasekaran et al. [345] demonstrated the application of computational fluid dynamics modelling to enhance the electrochemical characteristics of the proton-conducting fuel cell (PCFC) system. Methods for predicting crack initiation and delamination in SOFCs were presented through computational models of various stress effects in SOFC fabrication and operation, such as residual stress, oxidation stress, creep stress, chemical expansion, and thermal stress [346–348]. Several reviews have noted the effectiveness of the distribution of relaxation times (DRT) method for analyzing the electrochemical performance of air electrodes in SOCs. This method is based on complex nonlinear least squares analysis of electrochemical impedance spectroscopy [349,350]. Recent developments in the understanding of the mechanism of reaction processes occurring in SOC, such as ORR and OER, have been summarized in reviews on the conventional LSM electrode [34], perovskite-based electrodes [28,351], perovskite nanostructured electrodes [352,353], and heterostructured electrodes [186]. Osinkin [354] has presented a detailed review of the kinetics of hydrogen oxidation at SOFC anodes. Fan et al. [355] presented a comprehensive review of recent achievements in CH4 reforming, observing the mechanisms of catalytic processes in SOFCs. In addition, reviews by Wei et al. [356,357] have collected contributions on the mechanisms of fuel conversion in SOC, including the applications and future perspectives of perovskite catalysts with nanoparticle exsolution, in the case of CH4 reforming. Faro et al. [358] have reviewed the direct oxidation of dry fuels. Zhang et al. [359] have highlighted the advantages of using looping technology in the methane conversion process. Progress in the understanding of the mechanisms of the CH4 reforming reaction, degradation and performance have been summarized by Ye et al. [360] for H-SOCs and Thyssen et al. [261] for solid-state methane conversion reactors. The main aspects of the electrochemical synthesis of methanol [361] and ammonia [362,363] have also been discussed. Several recent reviews have discussed the current state of research on the mechanisms of electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO in SOECs [166,211,360,364–366] as well as the co-electrolysis of CO2 and H2O [360,366]. The concept of in-situ methanation in SOECs has been discussed by Biswas et al. [215]. However, only a few reviews have provided an overview of the components [367,368] and optimization capabilities [367] of SOECs. Recent achievements in green hydrogen technologies have been highlighted in reviews that consider water electrolysis [369–378], alkaline water electrolysis [379,380], solid oxide electrolysis [379,380], proton exchange membrane (PEM) water electrolysis [379,380], thermal catalysis [380,381], and electrochemical abstraction of hydrogen from light alkanes [369]. Recent progress in electrolysis technologies for hydrogen production has been observed by Sayem et al. [382] based on the data from the 107 patents from the Lens database. They presented a scheme for the application of electrolysis technology in hydrogen production, as shown in Fig. 12(b). The number of fuel cell patents exceeds the patents for other hydrogen production applications. 12 Electrochemical systems 12.1 SOFCs/SOECs The classification of solid oxide cells into general types and energy conversion efficiencies has been presented in corresponding reviews for SOFCs [383–385] and SOECs [384,386]. Kuterbekov et al. [383] were the first to attempt to classify all types of developed SOFCs and to describe their advantages and disadvantages. The conclusions showed that the anode-supported design of the two-chamber SOFC with oxygen-ion conducting electrolyte is the most suitable for operation at temperatures below 800 °C. Proton-conducting electrolyte SOFCs and electrolyte-free fuel cells were also identified as promising for low-temperature operation. However, further development is required before existing technologies can be commercialized. 12.2 Hybrid systems The integration of fuel cells that operate on hydrogen and hydrocarbon fuels with other types of energy systems, forming polygeneration or hybrid systems, is a promising strategy in sustainable energy technologies [387]. Fig. 13 (a) illustrates the schematic concept of SOFC-based polygeneration systems for producing additional electrical power, while Fig. 13(b) demonstrates that fuel cells coupled with a gas turbine (GT) can achieve electrical efficiencies above 60% [388]. Recently, there has been an overview of the design of energy systems based on SOFC integrated with gas processing plants [389–391] combined heat and power systems (CHP) [392–400], batteries [401,402], GT [388,403], carbon capture and storage systems [388], gasification systems [395,403,404], internal combustion engine systems [405,406], solar energy systems [407], and waste conversion systems [408]. 12.3 Gas separation membranes Gas separation membranes are utilized SOC technologies, such as catalytic membrane reactors [259], to produce syngas from hydrocarbon fuels. This is achieved by oxidizing the fuels with oxygen, which is separated from air using oxygen-permeable membranes [42,44,260]. Additionally, these membranes are used to capture CO2 and convert it into valuable chemicals with the aid of carbonate-ionic conductor membranes [44,409]. Fig. 14 (a and b) illustrates the schemes of oxygen separation and CO2 utilisation on the mixed ionic-electronic conductor membrane, respectively. The review [409] presents a comprehensive overview of membranes designed for CO2 conversion. These membranes can be classified into three types: mixed oxide-ionic and carbonate-ionic conductor membranes, mixed electronic and carbonate-ionic conductor membranes, and mixed electronic, oxide-ionic and carbonate-ionic conductor membranes. The chemical processes occurring in these membranes are illustrated in Fig. 14 (c–e). Borm et al. [410] and Li et al. [411] highlighted the potential of membrane technology for green hydrogen production using polymeric membranes. López-Fernández et al. [412] reviewed alkaline exchange membranes. The use of proton-conducting and proton exchange membranes has been evaluated for fuel cells [413,414], electrolyzers [415,416], and hydrogen production [414]. Additionally, previous studies [417–420] have examined the design and functional properties of oxide semiconductor-ionic conducting materials, which may have potential applications in the development of semiconductor-ionic membrane fuel cells. 12.4 Gas sensors The need to develop a commercially viable and highly effective hydrogen sensor has been highlighted by the use of hydrogen as a replacement for fossil fuels in power generation equipment. The hydrogen sensor operates by reacting hydrogen with the sensing electrode, which produces electron transfer and hydrogen oxidation at the anode, and oxygen reduction at the cathode. The concentration of hydrogen is then detected by the resulting change in electrical signal, as illustrated in Fig. 15 . The reviews [421–423], considering the recent achievements in the design of solid electrolyte based electrochemical hydrogen sensors, analyze the main types of hydrogen sensors, which include amperometric, impedimetric and potentiometric sensors, the schematics of which are summarized in Fig. 15. Gorbova et al. [424] discussed recent progress in the design of electrochemical gas sensors based on oxygen ion and proton-conducting electrolytes. These sensors are capable of detecting gases such as carbon oxides (CO x ), nitrogen oxides (NO x ), oxygen (O2), ammonia (NH3), and humidity (steam). Solid electrolyte electrochemical gas sensors are advantageous due to their high sensitivity, accuracy, fast monitoring, low cost, and simple design when compared to traditional optical and catalytic control devices. In addition, the information about ammonia sensors [425,426], ethanol sensors [427], and biosensors [428] could be found in the corresponding reviews. 13 Conclusions and perspectives This review examines recent trends and future directions in the design of functional materials for high-temperature solid oxide electrochemical cells. Due to the large number of research activities related to this topic, with over 8,000 items published since 2020, it is challenging to analyze all of them and provide comprehensive information on achievements and unresolved issues at the same time. Instead, this work provides an overview of other review papers (∼430 items) that enable the collection of the most important data in all fields related to functional materials, including electrolytes, oxygen electrodes, fuel electrodes, interconnects, glass sealants, coatings, interlayers, and membrane materials. The readers can be referred to specific review articles of their own interest based on the existing sections. This work presents a double-level system that links reviews with origin information sources, allowing for a concise presentation of a large amount of published information. It may be useful for students and scientists specializing in electrochemistry, solid state ionics, energy technology, and materials science. It is important to note that since the revised version of this work was prepared, several new reviews have been published in the literature. These reviews were not included in the presented scientometric analysis and other sections. However, we believe they should be mentioned to provide more complete information regarding solid oxide materials and related electrochemical cells. These new reviews deal with oxygen-ionic electrolytes [429], electrode materials for SOFCs and SOECs [430–433], electrode materials for PCFCs and PCECs [434,435], materials for SOFCs and SOECs (general reviews) [436–442], degradation-related processes [443,444], MIEC materials [445], solid oxide electrochemical cells for synthesis of chemicals or energy production from non-H2 sources [446–450], solid oxide electrochemical cells characterization [451,452], and SOFC-based hybrid power systems [453]. Elena Filonova received her Diploma in Chemistry and Ph.D. degree from the Ural State University (USU), Ekaterinburg, Russia in 1995 and 1998, respectively. In 1999–2010, she worked as an Assistant Professor and then as an Associate Professor at the Chair of Physical Chemistry, Chemistry Department, USU. From 2010 to present, she is working as an Associate Professor at the Department of Physical and Inorganic Chemistry, Institute of Natural Sciences and Mathematics, Ural Federal University (Ekaterinburg, Russia). Her research interests include development of synthesis techniques, characterization of materials and investigation of their functional properties for SOFC and catalysis applications. Muhammad Bilal Hanif is currently employed as a Senior Researcher at the Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Comenius University in Bratislava, Slovakia. Additionally, he collaborates with the Polish Academy of Sciences in Krakow, Poland, under the guidance of Dr. hab. Michał Mosiałek. Recognizing his achievements, he has been honored with the Young Scientists award from XJTU, China, and has received the UK grant for the years 2021–2024 at Comenius University Bratislava, Slovakia. His research primarily focuses on solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, and solid-state batteries for energy conversion applications. Martin Motola is a leader of the Materials Innovation & Advances (MIA) lab and currently works as an Associate Professor at the Department of Inorganic Chemistry, Faculty of Natural Sciences, Comenius University Bratislava, Slovakia. His primary research focus is related to energy storage and conversion including solid oxide fuel and electrolysis cells, batteries, and solar cells. MIA also conducts research on environmental remediation including hydrogen production, and water and air treatment. Dr. Motola earned his Ph.D. from Comenius University Bratislava in Slovakia and post-doc under the supervision of Dr. Jan M. Macak. Sajid Rauf received his Ph.D. degree from the School of Physics, Hubei University, China (2021). He received his Master's degree in Physics from the Department of Physics, COMSATS University Islamabad, Pakistan (2016). He remained as a Research Assistant at the Interdisciplinary Research Centre for Biomedical Materials, CUI, Pakistan from 2015 to 2017. He worked on bio-enzymatic fuel cell in the Department of Chemistry, Université Grenoble Alpes, France (2017–2018). Currently, he is working as a Full-Time Research Associate Professor in College of Mechatronics and Control Engineering, Shenzhen University, China. His research interests include the design and development of novel perovskite semiconductor oxide materials and their heterostructures for low-temperature solid oxide fuel cells and electrolysis cells. Dmitry Medvedev is a head of the Laboratory of Electrochemical Devices based on Solid Oxide Proton Electrolyte at the Institute of High-Temperature Electrochemistry (IHTE, Ekaterinburg, Russia) and a Head of the Hydrogen Energy Laboratory at the Ural Federal University (Ekaterinburg, Russia). He received his Ph.D. in 2012 and Dr. Habil. in 2019, both in the field of high-temperature electrochemistry. His research activity deals with synthesis and design of modernized functional materials for energy conversion devices, such as solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, sensors, and oxygen permeable membranes.

coredata.dc:description: Complex oxides are an important class of materials with enormous potential for electrochemical applications. Depending on their composition and structure, such complex oxides can exhibit either a single conductivity (oxygen-ionic or protonic, or n-type, or p-type electronic) or a combination thereof generating distinct dual-conducting or even triple-conducting materials. These properties enable their use as diverse functional materials for solid oxide fuel cells, solid oxide electrolysis cells, permeable membranes, and gas sensors. The literature review shows that the field of solid oxide materials and related electrochemical cells has a significant level of research engagement, with over 8,000 publications published since 2020. The manual analysis of such a large volume of material is challenging. However, by examining the review articles, it is possible to identify key patterns, recent achievements, prospects, and remaining obstacles. To perform such an analysis, the present article provides, for the first time, a comprehensive summary of previous review publications that have been published since 2020, with a special focus on solid oxide materials and electrochemical systems. Thus, this study provides an important reference for researchers specializing in the fields of solid state ionics, high-temperature electrochemistry, and energy conversion technologies.
